39401414.review:
An unfortunate fact with these business tycoon type games is that they simulate reality a little too well. Which is to say, the qualifiers for success are complex and unreadable. Here, you can watch the market, plan carefully, hire experts, and produce outstanding-quality software and not get anywhere, slowly bleeding money out of every pore or just barely keeping your head above water. Or, you can produce a single art application as your very first project, make ten million dollars, and effectively have beaten the game.

Essentially, due to all the factors involved and their nebulous effect on each other, it comes out to a dice roll. The game is fascinating from a certain perspective, but I have never been able to tell if there's a strategy beyond surviving long enough to get lucky enough that you get enough money to not have to play it anymore.

While I reccomend this game I do have a couple problems with it, even if it is still in Early Access these are features I would like to see implemented.

but first lets go with the pros
+The Most advanced software dev tycoon game I have EVER played, while still being fun! good job guys!
+Building development is fun, and keeps me going on this game! I love seeing what I can build.
+The game is completely fun, and entertaining.
+The graphics work for a game like this, no need for realism in a tycoon game
+For the most part the sound design is nice

cons
-the same song is played WAY too much! please add a few more to keep the soundtrack interesting
-The tutorials had me more interested in skipping them than anything, glad to see you are trying, but they weren't engaging enough.
-The game takes a little bit to get used to, On my first attempt I quit and didnt touch it for months (partly because, well.... zelda and stuff.
- There needs to be the ability to split rooms up or something, I dont know if it is already there, but I haven't found it, and it should be there.
- There should be the ability to change the price on a product after it is released, like in the month of december, if I released a game like 5-6 months ago, I should be able to drop the retail price on the game to help boost sales. This would seriously help out a product that has been priced too high from being dead meat for it's entire life span.
-the competitors, while a great addition, are still a little... too simple, they could really use some more flare, I know they can buy companies and stuff but... eh?
-the news stuff while a great addition, could also use some more meat to it, maybe add more stuff to the competitors that allows it to start being opened at the begining of each month? like right at the beginning, allowing you to read up on what your competitors are doing, what your subsidaries are doing, and what the people think of your products. This way, it is a little more intrusive, but at the same time more interesting.

39163494.review:
Everything I wanted and wished for in a Tycoon/Management Game!!!

I bought this game with some logical amounts of hesitation due to the dreaded Early Access Tag, but I am glad to say that it gave me a taste of what Early Access used to be and hope to become one day. This is what early access wanted to achieve, bringing light to a game that otherwise might have gone by, giving power and hope to a passionate developer. Help smaller games gain a following and a growing community. 

Enough though for the early access rant. Let's dig into the game.

First off, I hate comparing games as each game deserves to be views as a unique thing, but this game and some aspects of it remind me of Game Dev. Tycoon, a game that I really love. Software Inc. is like the bigger, better Game Dev. Tycoon. Much deeper and with more choices depending what you are going to develop.

Listing some of the things that make this game great (even in this Alpha State):

First thing that caught my attention,

-The music although nothing really special, is calming, chill and compliments the feel of the game really good.

-Time Eater... I got into the game with every chance i got and loved to see the hour clock go by

-Decorating and Building is a big aspect of the game as you have to take into account, when building, first of all the cost, then stuff like rent and temperature. All the employees you get, except you, are affected from thing like the temperature of the room they are in, the "Decor" score, privacy when working and lots more things.

-Tons of Customizations, not only in the visual aspect of your building or Character, but in everything concerning your software. From Development to Marketing, Destribution, Printing copies and many more the game is full of choices that will either leave you scraping to get by, rushing products out there or leave you with more money you know what to do with.

-Making something actually sell for the first time is a feeling of acomplishment that I cannot describe. Making your first "Big Hit" on the market feels amazing though you have to be carefull not to "overextend" your company too early on.

-Things ACTUALY make sense. Making an Operating System is far more profitable in the 80s than later as the market was still pretty new and open to new things. Making a Game in the 2010s is far more profitable than trying to compete with companies makis OSs who have been doing it since the 80s.

-All the micromanaging in general is what made me buy this Game. Thinking about where to build each room(Server room, Dining room, break room) so it does not affect the workflow of the employees. Managing all the salaries and costs. Placing and tasking each Team with a different thing, trying to find the most efficient, cost effective, fastest way to make a new product with the best quality possible. 

Finishing up, I think that this game deserves a great future. The developer seems to love it, being active with forum questions and general support. It is a game every Steam User interested in Tycoon/Management Type games should give a chance as I'm sure he/she/it/they will love it. I sure do! 

Thank you for spending the time reading, I hope if you get the game, like it as much as I do.

38882063.review:
Software Inc. is already a thorough simulation of what it's like to develop software both at the scale of two kids developing indie games in their garage and the scale of hundreds of employees in a multi-floor office tower. The process of developing an individual software package is detailed, the process of developing multiple software packages that are inter-dependend is intense. You can build a game using existing 2d, 3d editing software and an existing engine, or you can develop your own engine and your own editing software in house. You can even release your own OS and then build a whole suite of software around it like an office suite (From a simple wordprocessor to a whole package of office software with spreadsheets, presentation software, clipart, etc.) and anti-virus software. You can even just play datacenter/host for the online storage needs of other companies. 

There's a lot to do, and that's not evening mentioning the possibility of trading stocks, IP buying/trading and other parts of the economic simulation.

There's just as much detail to building your own office, which allows more freedom to build walls and place objects than the Sims by allowing you to resize the grid, rotate the grid and re-colour every single object. 

But it's not entirely finished. The interface is not ideal, the tutorials are unhelpful and there's not yet enough options to customize software and differentiate yourself from your competition. However, I wholeheartedly recommend Software Inc. to any fan of simulation games, from the old Theme Hospital and RCT, to Dwarf Fortress and Prison Architect.

I recently desided to give it another go and was it fun when I started to undderstand how things work. 
I went form 2.5 hours gameplay to 41 hours total gameplay in a matter of days developing my software house from an overburdened team to a super enterprise.

One thing that I really enjoyed is the gameplay mechanics where in the begining you need to do everything yourself, delegate the work amongst the teams,
managing the marketing and support and as your company gets larger you are able to create and assign a project office to handle these for you.

Not only does the project office help manage your software development and releases but it gives you TIme to furher increase the business as you can have multiple project offices at once doing their own things, but you are also then able to work on investments in other software companiees which is fully dynamic.

During my last gameplay I witnessed alot of new companies starting and also witnessed some of the older mega companies lose millions and my bigest competetor even lost billions and ended up going bankrupt, This feature really keeps things going as the batle is ever ongoing for the top spot.

I had a great time building my super enterprise and though it is in Eraly Access I was supprised as during my 41 hour gameplay I did not encounter any majour bugs and only experianced one game crash.

Best early acces game I ever bought.

In short: 
A super software developer + business simulator which tries to mimic real life business management.

Longer:

Every tried game dev tycoon? Ever felt it was too simplistic / limited?
Say hello to Software Inc.
A superb business simulator where one gets to create a range of different products while trying to keep up with:
Wages, rent, maintenance, stocks, competition, competition release dates, distribution, marketing, bloody project management, being a professor sending your dear employees to school, ... 
Micro-management lovers, here is your new gem.

Building an office -> become richer -> building a bigger office -> become even more richer -> build a freaking apple hq style compound -> become the sole market leader in every single industry *evil corp laugh*.

Perfect Microsoft / Apple / Nvidia / EA Games business sim.
8/10 (in early alpha).

38686924.review:
Alright! I've been playing non-stop for the past week and I think I've done everything there is to do and more. Overall, great game! It adds a ton to the genre while maintaining the usual core features. Here are some but not all of my thoughts... I might add to this post later.

----What I LIKED the most...----

--Building offices. This was extremely fun... Getting the rooms right and positioning everything to minimize worker downtime while maintaining aesthetics was an amazing experience. Most of the productivity is lost through workers having to walk across a carpark or to go to a meeting room or get food. I think I came up with something quite scalable and optimal. I think logistics is a massive selling point of the game and building on this would be a great decision.

--The market and company system. This was so much better than what's in Game Dev Tycoon. Managing competition and watching the market is really fun and engaging. My strategy is always rush to dominate one or two markets and shut down competitors, just like in real life I guess. Perhaps a little more depth though. I think the stock system has huge potential but is very lacking atm.

--The early to mid game. By far the most fun part of the game is building up the company from nothing and trying to keep it afloat while the company rocks on the edge of chaos. There's an easy strategy where you have your founder develop an OS over 3 years and it will bring in 4+ million per month but even then the mid-game is still quite challenging. The late game needs to be overhauled.

----What can be SIGNIFICANTLY improved----

--Managing teams and employees. It is VERY clunky and sometimes even bugs out.

There should be a way to set HR management and time schedules on multiple teams at the same time. You need 3 of each team to cover three 8-hour shifts to maximise productivity. Multiply that with several teams and adding additional teams and it gets really tedious.

I don't know what's up with HR education but it's either EXTREMELY slow or it just doesn't work. I just had a game where three identical teams with the same setting except for arrival/departure time. Two teams were sent to class and one team never gets sent. And it appears they always were sent on 1-month courses. It's better to just manually mass train employees on 3-month courses (Good thing that you can send multiple at the same time).

It should be allowed to reserve or prioritize parking spaces for specific teams or employees and staff. Currently, it seems to just flood the carpark from right to left, which is highly inefficient.

Also the functionality to set multiple roles on employees (Yes I heard it's coming in A10... Just wanted to mention it here).

--Products and technologies. Right now all the different products are basically the same in terms of gameplay. X amount of code. Y amount of art. And a combination of required specializations. Similar for tech and research. Each just adds a little more to a specific product but nothing really unique. Art/code/design are also very similar. Same workspaces (Yes, I know about the add-ons you can place next to computers), and extremely similar development mechanics. The overall effect is extremely repetitive, grindy, and bland gameplay.

This can be spiced up in many ways. Different types of workstations and environments for different specializations and sub-specialisations. Office furnishings that boost specific jobs but are detrimental to others. Technologies that add unique requirements and pros/cons to a product. Some of the technology combos don't make sense. A MMO game with local multiplayer? A touch OS with no GUI? These should all have a huge negative impact on sales but right now it seems like you just want to research everything tick all the boxes.

--The interface. It does very little to lessen the apparent complexity of the game. Every window is information overload. I'm 100% used to it now though and see the value of all the information but when I first started out it was VERY dizzying. Many windows can be simplified in ways such as grouping columns that are highly related together and apart from others, being able to collapse columns and sub-windows and setting some less-important information panels/columns to be collapsed on default to lessen the initial impact. There also no icons that allow for quick recognition anywhere apart from the buttons in the main UI. Everything is labeled with text including action buttons. Pop-up tooltips at the cursor when first opening a window would also be really good.

The WORST thing is the list of current tasks at the right. At first, it's great but as my company grew to a very large size it was quite hellish to manage that list. Even just reversing the order and putting new items at the top of the list would help massively.

--Building rooms and mass placing objects is very clunky. A MASSIVE improvement here would be the ability to place snap and guidelines on the grid.

A marquee tool to select objects would also be extremely helpful and time-saving. A lot of the time I want to select some of objects X, Y, and Z in a room but not all of them. Like just the printers or workstations in the corner or whatever. I have to individually select what I want at that point.

----What I absolutely HATED and I think should be just scrapped----

--Project Management. Either I'm not using it right or this absolutely SUCKS. It takes years to finish a project and the end completed product sucks. Not to mention that it starts marketing way too early.

BUT EVEN if project management was as good as manually managing projects I wouldn't like this feature. This feature aims to completely trivialize a huge portion of the game. Managing projects is quite an engaging part of the game. Sometimes I need to take an art team off a project to prevent it from going overboard. Sometimes I need to re-prioritize teams to prevent a disaster with support. Managing multiple projects at the same time and getting it all on schedule feels amazing but that might just be me.

--Contract Work. Also might just be me but this is probably my most hated part of in this game genre. It feels like a chore to do at the start of the game. It's not engaging or in-depth or challenging in any way. No thought and minimal strategy involved. It's a bore. Completely revamp contracts so they 1. scale into the late game and 2. are fun and in-depth. This is an area where the genre needs big innovation.

----Other Suggestions----

--Modding. It seems right now mods are limited to just adding predefined product and tech archetypes. I'd really like a much more extensive mod system, if that's possible. I wanted to create a mod that adds and improves to HR management but it didn't seem like that was possible.

--Reviewer employees. How about permanent employees that constantly review the development of games? An estimated score will be shown at the development panel of the right and constantly updated as the reviewers work. Highly skilled reviewers know how to be unbiased.

--Resource import system. Products with extensive features need additional resources to develop like arts and craft supplies. I think this would work really well with the hardware mods. Those mods right now don't really make sense with all hardware being developed on a computer and then printed or even digitally distributed.

Overall

Gameplay: 8.5/10. Good stuff! Quite innovative, much more-so than the other games of the genre! Needs a lot of polish but the core game loop feels amazing.

Graphics: 8/10. I suspect the dev went with a typical looking low-poly unity style because it's a one-man team. Though for one person it's impressive. Though granted, I'm already lagging when 300+ employees change shifts.

Sound: 9.5/10. The music and effects are on-point! I like how when I zoom in on workers I can hear their chatter.

38196296.review:
A great (unfinished) software gem, and even now already a very impressive result for such a small dev team. 

It's fun and addictive to explore the possibilities, to create your perfectly fitting tams, put them into an optimized office layout and let them create successful software products. Rinse and repeat in bigger and bigger scale, managing all the little problems that you come across, and slowly turn the little shack that your "office" was in the beginning into a buzzing campus of innovation and prosperity. 

[b] Be aware: [/b]   
Some aspects of the game are quite unbalanced in the current state, which can change the game experience a lot (CMS production -> revenue and effort compared to games production / a few contracts are way too well payed...)
Some approaches can make the game very hard, some are making it way too easy. 

[b] What I would love to see in a final build and what is imo missing right now (from my real life experience at least: [/b] 

- Marketing option before the release: Especially when you have tons of money at your hand in the later game you should have more options to promote your product pre-release. (Hyping a bad product / raising the expectations too much could still have negative consequences, like loosing followers / reputation / reputation with the press)

- HR team / Learning and development: Should be needed in a company from a specific size onwards. HR should also be able to create in-house training options (including teachers that can become an invaluable asset to the company?)

- Team leads should play a bigger role (probably even come with perks?) and an absence of team leaders should lead to (more) negative consequences

- Localization options during software development / a localisation team or an outsourcing team for loc work?

- Community work and event organisation (Could be part of Marketing? I guess Marketing it's already meant ike that, but more details would be great: Focus on Social Media / print / TV / Events during campaigns? Even create your own event?)

- The "All available software on the market" screen needs better filter options

- Last, but not least: [u]Game development should have more genres and options to define the size of the game[/u]

I am looking forward to play this again in a few months, and to try out some mods! <3

Still a little rough around the edges, but it already has a lot of fine qualities that make it a worthwile purchase. It definitely itches the scratch for non-casual Management/Tycoon/Simulation type games I've been having recently.


+ very in-depth building mechanics, with blueprints, cloning, flexible grids, etc

+ interesting software development

38109199.review:
С8ка... Кажется игра дала сбой.. 
Основав компанию по разработке ПО (В частности осей для ПК), на свои никчемные 300.000 рублей (Рус рубли - кастомные. Перековырял конфиг), я решил торгануть акциями (а чем черт не шутит).. В феврале 80го года я приобрел пакет акций GYGABYTE inc., которые к тому времени летели на глубокое дно, с ценой в 150к рублей за свой никчемный пакет.
Но уже в марте процент пакета выскачил за облака. GYGABYTE прямо сорвали куш на своей свеженькой материнке, которую расхватали с полок на ура! Свой нифиговый плюс с дохода я решил отправить в фондовую биржу. (правильно! Нафиг в игре про разработку игр-программ-и запчастей для ПК(Akrotech Hardware) что то разрабатывать, если есть акции!!). Получив пару слюнявых под дых и упав почти на дон, я все таки сорвал куш, а потом ещё один.. И ещё один.. И уже в середине года я начинаю активно скупать акции других организаций... Когда до меня дошло, что на руках у меня фактически по 80% акций от каждой существующей компании, я не задумываясь, начал разорять их, выкупая акции подчистую и присваивая их разработки.. В конце 80го года, на производственном рынке и рынке разработок не осталось никого.. Кроме меня разумеется... 
Народ трепещет, бизнесмены в шоке.. Я сам не далек от них.. Денег до жопы жуй, а поддерживать более 6 сотен наименований различной продукции - не хватает рук и сил. 
Мелкие компании начинают зарождаться в начале 81го года со своим жалким капиталом в 3млн рублей.. Сразу скупаю у них 90% акций и всучиваю им часть из это туевой хучи товаров, скомунизженных у "корпораций" конца 80го года... 
И мелкие рыпнуться не могут, ибо я могу тут же их сместить с рынка.. И у меня нескончаемый поток отечественного рубля.. По мимо их дохода трясу с них от 15 до 25% за дистрибуцию в добровольно-принудительном порядке.. 
На минуточку, мой ежемесячный доход составляет 980 млн рублей! 
Сижу и думаю, кажется я совсем скоро заработаю все деньги мира... 

Посидел, блин, ночку за экономическим симулятором....

38103080.review:
This is amazing! I came from Game Dev tycoon and also play the Sims and this really combines the important aspects of both into one cheerful game. I only have about 30 hours in, but my company is worth well over 2 Billion with hundreds of employees. I work for a tech company in real life and feel as though this matches pretty well in terms of teams, strategies, chemistry, roles etc. The UX took me a couple of days to figure out because there is so much that you can do, but once I started to get the hang of it, it felt pretty intuitive.


I still haven't been able to keep all of my employees happy, even though they all get free food, their OWN offices and a huge campus, but you never will keep everyone happy. Support is my biggest challenge at this point. I'm so good at releasing stellar products that hundreds of support staff cant keep up. But that's a GOOD problem to have.


I did run into issues with contract work at the beginning of the game. I couldn't get my player to begin work on one. But I then went right into an OS and had no troubles, made a few million and the rest is history. Also, resizing windows & resolutions has given me some issues in terms of not being able to see the 'x' to close some modals, not being able to drag them either. Also, sometimes my spreadsheets lose all of their data if I scroll all the way to the right, but if you quit to the menu and restart the game it fixes itself.

Overall it's amazing that this is a 1 person show. It's so playable, blows games that took thousands of people to make right out of the water. BE WARNED: this is extremely addicting, especially if you're interested in a full-control tech sim. So happy I found this, keep up the great work!

37747424.review:
DO YOU LIKE TYCOON/BUSINESS MANAGEMENT GAMES?!

Well despite being anti-capitalist, I really do. Don't ask me why, I honestly couldn't tell you. Maybe I just really like micromanagement.

If you, like me, enjoy games like this for some inexplicable reason, you should pick up Software Inc. The premise is simple, starting in the 1970s and with one person, you build a software company from the ground up, complete with design teams, programmers, artists, a marketing department, server farms, and an office building that you design yourself.

Think Game Dev Tycoon meets The Sims.

You can create a small company that solely makes RTS games, or you can create a megacorporation that designs operating systems and buys out smaller subsidiary companies. It's up to you, the player.
The thing that sets this game apart from others like it, is how complex it's game systems actually are, while remaining simple to understand and "game-like". Most other games that set out to achieve what this game does, are either overly complex, or too dumbed down. This game maintains a perfect balance between complexity and simplicity.

The one negative thing I can say about it is that once you figure out what works to make a profitable company, it becomes way too easy. However, this isn't where the meat of the game's fun lies. It lies within the satisfaction of being creative within the game's systems. Building a cool office building, designating tasks for your individual teams, finally making making a piece of software that sells millions of copies. Stuff like that.

In conclusion, if you like tycoon and business simulation games, Software Inc is a must have.

37724857.review:
Das beste Software- und Spieleentwicklungs-Tycoon-Spiel der letzten Jahre, oder sogar überhaupt. Das Spiel bekommt einigermaßen regelmäßig Updates und es ist ein Entwicklungsfortschritt spürbar. Durch den Workshop können Einrichtungsgegenstände und ganze neue Softwaretypen zum Spiel hinzugefügt werden. Man kann nicht nur Teams einteilen und entscheiden, welche Software entwickelt werden soll, sondern auch Vertragsarbeiten abschließen und so beispielsweise zum Hosting-Dienst werden. Die Software, die man entwickeln muss, ändert sich über die Jahre, der ganze Markt mit Konkurrenten wird realistisch simuliert. Noch dazu kommt, das man das Gebäude, in dem die eigene Softwarefirma sitzt, in einem gut gelungenen Baumodus sehr frei gestalten kann - oder auch ein von anderen Nutzern erstelltes Gebäude aus dem Steam Workshop herunterladen kann.
Für mich ist Software Inc. schon jetzt ein spaßiges Spiel und gleichzeitig eine glaubbare Simulation - den geringen Preis von 14€ ist es auf jeden Fall wert!

37582959.review:
This game is heart and soul of what it means to build a pillar of the simulation business strategy genere. This is for every hard core management sim gamer who loves endless options, multiple paths to success, and a more true-to-life feel. You will be completely involved from getting your one room no glory software company started, to dominating the industry along multiple product channels via quality, talent, or sheer market power.

Want to run a game software company that actually listens to its gamers? BAM you can do that!
Want to build an impressive server company contracting your hosting space? BOOM done!
Looking to dominate the OS industry, or heck a whole landslide of industries?! OR the entire software stock market?! Or or the world?!!! Okay myb not the world... but hey he who writes the code makes the rules.

I love the loving care that has been put into the core balance and mechanics of the simulation, some top-notch work with more to come from the looks of recent updates. IF I had to choose a con... if I must... I'd like to see more artisty put into props, and fluid movement to workers. Although the art style I think is more deliberatly vague. Either way, this is Early Release and blows out of the water other management sim games for sheer detail.

Stop waiting for the release! It's a solidly awesome game right now!

37425449.review:
Software inc is one of those games you find in your que, and you think to yourself "I dont know if this looks i interesting"
Trust me it is.

Software inc is one of those hidden gems in steam you find when despretly looking for a game to play, i saw it on the store front one day and didnt even give it a second glance, then saw it in my que a week later. i gave it a shot and i've spent too much time on it to be right for a game in early access. This game is cheep, packed full of content supprisingly for a early access title and fairly detailed.

The low poly graphics make this game stand out among the other management type games on steam and give it a uniqe look. With character customization and building aspects, the game may not have the details of a triple A game, but the simplistic style will have you focusing on what acually matters, the management.

You create and manage software, as the title inplys you create a comanpy as well. You hire, fire and manage each employee including your own character on projects you want to create. you give the project a name, go through the 3 stages -> Pre Production(Design) -> Production(Development) -> Post Production(Support/Marketing) and pray that you allocated your team and time right to create a sucessfull project. If you do you create millions, if you dont, you go bankrupt, unless you are already a multi billionair taking advangte of the games mechanics

The game includes a stock market, a highly abusable(at the moment) system that allows you to invest stocks into any company on the market, thing is, you can abuse this system by looking for new companys that startup with an OS. they will always make millions and in year 1 without making anything, you're already a multi-millionair. But even with that the one thing that kept me engaged was the micro-mangament and the little details that kept me interested

Software can depend on other software, your OS can become big the next day because someone released a huge game for it and now you are making millions. You might be thinking "Well thats it? i make money to make money", its not that. the game keeps you engaged and on your toes most of the time when you are making that money. If you are like me you will be so focused on trying to get the perfect software, you lose track of time.

OVERALL:
This game is highly addicting, highly rewarding and generally fun. The building mechanic will take hours away from your life while managing your staff and prodcuts will cut your time even more. I highly recommend this game for anyone looking for a good managment game on the market. You will not be disapointed by the low price and fun gameplay

[Pros]
-Building System
-Very Detailed
-No Handholding
-Micro-Managment
[Cons]
-Marketing is vauge
-Stock market is too broken [over powered]
-Fans make no sense
-Bugs

37420085.review: Долгое время не покупал игру - смущал неказистый вид и ранний доступ с большой ценой (как мне казалось). Наконец, решился и понял, что совершал глупость, потому что не покупал ее раньше - игра отличная и глубокая симуляция софт-компании. Глубокая уже сейчас, несмотря на ранний доступ. Уже скоро я привык и к виду игры, и потихоньку изучил все особенности, коих там десятки, создав свою супер-корпорацию. Только некоторые возможности игры: многогранный редактор зданий, позволяющий построить свой офис мечты для каждого сотрудника с учетом шума, освещения и пр.; возможность нанимать сотрудников, создавать отделы, назначать начальников, передавать начальникам нудные функции по работе с персоналом отдела и проектами; разнообразные проекты с ветками исследований и патентами; страхование работников от несчастий и управление резервным фондом; биржа акций, возможность купли/продажи акций компаний и брендов с полным выкупом или подчинением в качестве дочерних компаний; реалистичная симуляция конкуренции на разных рынках (мне может показалось, но я наблюдал прямо настоящую борьбу компаний, банкротства и рождения новых фирм, борьбу друг с другом за разные отдельные рынки, а не только с игроком, попытки компаний выкупить друг друга, борьбу за успешные бренды...) и многое другое. Раньше считал лучшей игрой такого жанра Mad Games Tycoon - теперь моя любимая будет эта.

If you love these types of games in the style of economic simulator, Game Dev Tyccon or Mad Game Tycoon, then you'll definitely love this one. Lots of options to choose from when you make money. For making a software its the same, at first you have a limited selection of software you can make which makes sense since you don't have a lot to play with. The game can become very complex and thats a welcome addition. Have a team leader and assign them to a team. Multiply that by 5 or 10 and that becomes a headache which transfoms into a micromanagment. I love it.

The building aspect is not to be neglected. Its very important to make a building that your whole team will go along and have maximum efficiency. Its also good to note that the developer still updates this game today as of this writting.

36750023.review:
So far a very good sim game.

The complexities of managing physical space in your office, staff's needs, consumer's needs, marketing your products, creating your products, and distributing your products are all on that fine edge of being just complex enough to make the game interesting without being mind numbing.

This is a good 'chill out' game if you enjoyed other business sim games.This an important distinction because if you don't like simulation games, this will not be for you.

The music can be a bit repetitive, but it's far from terrible. The aesthetic, while not focused on realism or fancy graphics, gets the point across and is very clear to understand at a glance.

For an early access game, it's incredibly well polished as I've yet to encounter any bugs.

The company that made this, Coredumping, is not well known in this industry, here's hoping they make a name for themselves with this title.

I was 100% completely happy with this game when it launched. I'm astouded how much was added after the core mechanic was in place. I would have sold Software Inc 2, as what the game is now.

I could gripe about challenge. I find the most challenging part of the game very early on. You gather a small pile of money, and then the struggle is to turn that pile, into a team and a project that will keep you afloat long enough to strike it rich. I always end up rich, pretty quickly after, either through luck or strategy. Then with 100 mill in the bank, I build a massive compound, and grow bored of micromanaging my 70 teams. With so much money under me I can do whatever and it doesn't matter. 
I wish there was one more design element, so that it mattered how you set buildings up. Once you put your espresso machines into closets near the work stations, there's little else that matters. Perhaps Software Inc 3 will include security or espionage. Something to make the design and hiring practices matter more.
But I love this game and I've played it a ton, and at that price, you cant lose, unless you thought you were buying WWE Medals of Smackdown Honor.

[h1]I'll do a simple, detailed review of this once I'm done.[/h1]

[b]Experience so far?[/b]

I haven't even past so much progress yet, but the complexity of Software Inc. is what kept me offguard in the first two hours. However, you can't ignore the fact that the game doesn't want you to have a simple start just by making video games, softwares and what not. It wants you to learn every single of it, and how you execute it.

While I haven't past some hours on this game yet, I can only tell you that you have to [b]stray away from this game if you are truly unfamiliar of what you are going to face.[/b] One of these is just how detailed you need to make your work on something small, which actually pays off in the right way you do it.

This type of gameplay however, is what keeps me running for success, no matter the hiccups along the way. Sure it'll take hours to learn everything from simply managing your company to creating a software/program to reaching success. Should I recommend it though? Yes. [b]That is if you pay attention to the tutorial and know what you are absolutely doing to keep your company to maintain first base.[/b]

And what if that isn't your type? There are other sim development games out there to try out that doesn't involve these complexities. So something like Game Dev Tycoon, or even the better Mad Games Tycoon will ease that pain a bit.

36445676.review:
This game goes to show that a tiny, one-man dev studio can create a more interesting, engaging, addictive, and deep game than companies with budgets in the tens of millions.

The graphics are really pleasant to look at -- kind of a memory of a simpler time in computer gaming, but with a really modern feel. The gameplay is EXTREMELY accessible -- it's a sort of buffet where you can attempt to manage as many elements as you feel comfortable with. The game doesn't force anything on you.

I felt comfortable as a new player learning the basics, doing contracts and attempting my first few (failed) software projects.

I still feel the exact same way now that I'm trying some of the deeper or more complex features of the game -- project management, strategically picking outsourcing jobs to affect competitors and stock prices, renting out my hosting infrastructure, and building large office towers.

I can't recommend this game enough. It's the perfect sweet spot between realism, sandbox simulation, and super-fun management gameplay, without ever getting formulaic, boring, or repetitive. There's no "right answer" -- just a fun sandbox simulation about building a tech company.

My favorite game in a long time.

36417012.review: Having played most dev games around, I have to say this game is really worth the purchase. It is probably not revolutionary in the genre, but it adds a few elements and it offers a very enjoyable gameplay. The "build" mode is great fun and definitely a big plus, Software Inc. also introduces a nice automation system (Project Management) that none of its competitors has. I think tycoon games always need good automation systems if you don't want to go insane with micro-management in late game! It is not an easy game and has a relatively steep learning curve, which is a plus for me, but others might not feel the same way. Even in pre-release, it is very playable and you can even forget it is an incomplete game (very rare thing for a pre-release!). I hope the developer keeps on building on the huge potential this game has, but I warmly recommend it even as it is to anyone who loves complex simulation games with a bit of challange in it!

36303815.review:
[b]Summary[/b]

This game has a lot of potential and is quite playable right now. At present, however, it requires a lot of micromanagement which can be really tedious if you’re running a larger company.

I fully recommend it and the dev is quite active so it’s good to support him, but I hope that they will add some really necessary quality of life features such as an automation of smaller projects or better teamwork inside your teams without the need to assign dozens of rooms to small teams. I will elaborate futher in this review.

[b]What works[/b]
1. The way you’re designing programs - it allows a very deep level of customization as the mods clearly show.
2. Mods - even now there are quite a few great mods that add a nice variety of features - new programs, new scenarios, and new furniture (you can even build a full bathroom thanks to them, not just the vanilla “poop machine”).
3. The team chemistry and different characteristics of your employees show promise and already allow you to have many different types of people in your company, some of which are easier to deal with, and some can really be a pain in the neck. 
4. The game simulates the market up until the moment you start your own business, meaning that there are many different programs and established corporations for you to compete with. It is a bit rudimentary as the whole world is treated as a one, huge market, but it’s ok. Although I really hope that in the future they will realistically simulate how market kept changing and globalizing - largely local in the 80s but global in the 90s and 00s,
5. The 80s - my favorite era of software development, full of pioneers and experiments. Not that many games include it and that’s a shame, 
6, Outsourcing - you don’t have to design everything yourself. You can make some good money working for someone else.
7. Marketing, press releases, release dates, announcements, ads - it’s all done pretty well but it’s weird that you can only buy ads AFTER the release (not counting press builds and announcements). 

[b]What needs some improvement[/b]
1. Individual skills - your employees must be the best in everything or the quality will suffer. You can’t have an algorithm expert who would be average with system stuff - he would lower the quality significantly. I think that the game should not let someone with poor skills in a certain area to do what he’s not good at. If he can, great, but you should be able to set a minimal level for each employee to contribute to each field - an algorithm expert who can’t do much else should do just that, and not endanger the whole project. 
2. Less micromanagement, Teams are a very good addition but you really need to create a lot of them. Artists are the worst - you usually require less art units than code ones and so artists finish the job sooner. If they’re in the same team as the programmers, you can’t just order them to stop and do something else. Not really a problem yet, but as teams shouldn’t share a room, you require a lot of smaller rooms which can get tedious - if a project requires 2 artists and you have 4 in your team, it will be finished slowly, the same when you have a 4 artists team and 2 projects that require 2 each. It's much better to create 2 separate teams but then you also need 2 rooms. Also, this screws up your leaders - instead of having one lead to help a larger group of maybe 10 employees, you need one to nanny 2 artists while the other handles 8 programmers and designers. Also, when you’re taking on several small project that someone outsources, you have to keep checking the progress - it won’t end automatically, and won’t even move to beta once all the required units of code are done.
3. Ability to rent offices in a larger building and move to a new building. Or repurpose an old warehouse. 
4. I would really love a dev support for somewhat realistic scenarios - like making sure that company A will produce X consoles in 1990 no matter what, while Microsoft will outclass non-human opponents like in real-life, which could then lead to great real-world mods,
5. Recommended employees - this one needs some overhaul. I understand that with coding you can’t really hire 50 programmers when you really need 5 and expect they’ll do it 10 times faster, and this could even lead to chaos, meaning that it would take even longer. That’s fine, although hiring 6 when 5 are recommended could speed things up, while in the game it only slowers it. Seemingly even if the programmer is currently training and not physically in the company, bothering no one. Artists, however, don’t work this way - they have certain bits to do, and do them, the smaller they are the faster they tend to do them. Hiring 3 artists when 1 is recommended should speed things up. Maybe not 3 times faster, but perhaps twice as fast.
6. Reputation - it seems like it’s as hard to build a reputation in the 80s as it is in the 2010s. It requires a lot of great releases to become noticed. I think that this should be somewhat overhauled, along with the market percentages I mentioned before. Currently there are only several workflow programs on the market and they already dominate it in the 1980, while there should be many less common ones instead and so if a company develops a truly outstanding product when the market is not yet saturated, that company should become a lot more famous than a company that develops a great CAD program today when there are a lot of those already, some for quite a long time. The same with new programs - it was easier to create a Spotify when there were no companies as large as Spotify today, than it would have been now. In 1980 most program types were new and there were no truly dominant companies yet and the game should reflect that.
7. The building designing part is qute cool but not perfect. It suffers from some poor design choices - you can’t for example build a room inside a room - consequently you can’t build a big rectangle and then add the rooms and if you do so, you’re kinda screwed.

Anyway, those are issues I can understand since it’s only Early Access. The game seems to be moving in a good direction and those shouldn’t leave an impression that this game is bad - it is definitely not.

I am a huge fan of economic simulations since Software Manager from 1994 for Amiga. That was my first one and I have played thousands of different ecosims until now. And I have to say, that this fine piece of art here is one of the best I have ever played. 

What I like the most about it is the huge number of options the player has but yet the interface presents all the options in a way that the player won't lose himself in thousands of windows with houndreds of buttons. Many thoughts have been put in the design of the GUI and the outcome is great.

There are so many comfortable automations that can be micromanaged still without the feeling of having to set up millions of options. Everything is well linked and comprehensible. 

There are so many different strategies you can try in this game. The possibilities seem to be endless. 

Considering the fact that this game is still in Alpha and it is only made by one guy than I really have to say that Software Inc. is a masterpiece. If you are a fan of deep eco-sims, don't wait any longer and buy this game! You won't regret that decision.

35537720.review:
Software Inc is a management game of creating a small software house and culturing it until it festers into a corporate blight upon the digital kingdom. You start by building a small room or two, staffed by a handful of programmers (or even just your company’s founder) and working on other people’s contracts. If you have the money or the courage, you can develop your own software.

There’s a decent amount of freedom in terms of how you achieve digital dominance. You can make editing tools for creators, business tools for offices, videogames for consoles and (given the time and expertise) even a whole operating system of your own. Selling these and moving onto the next big thing (command-line to GUI, 2D graphics to 3D graphics) will see you expand and grow, and all the while time advances, prompting panicked renovations as you install new computers to each of your employees’ desks in an effort to keep up with the competition.

Sadly, the products don’t appear as anything tangible – there’s no cardboard box to be proud of, or shots of how it looks on-screen. Instead your software appears as entries in the charts, or as reviews in the ‘Software Times’. Sometimes you’ll get a place in a Top 5 listicle and that’s always a good feeling. Then, next year, you’ll see your program’s position slip from 2nd place to 5th and you’ll be fuming. “What the hell is Lion X anyway?” you’ll scream.

35208412.review:
Has plenty of new features being added every month or so. Development is fairly slow, but it's one guy making the game, so that is kind of to be expected, and he keeps coming out with new updates and tweaks on a pretty regular schedule. For example, the latest Alpha 9.x build fixed a lot of the difficulty problems with the game that was in Alpha 8.x. Namely, the game was too easy.

Where before, you could amass millions of dollars after making one "Outstanding" quality product, you now actually have to plan your developments, your marketing, and your money stream to some extent over a longer period. It has made the game fairly challenging in the early stages and can be somewhat nail-bitingly tense as you try to put out software before your competition while building interest in your product, paying your employees, and trying to rationalize your budget with your income stream. Later updates promise to improve this to make it even more challenging to expand when you "make it, bigly."

The dev has a big roadmap on his website. The latest features map (25/9/17) include things like multiple roles for employees (each employee can have one role at the moment, or "any role", but this doesn't work with employees who are good at two separate things, but not three or four), more factor variables for software (currently there is only one major factor, which is "innovation", with other factors being more opaque), and even hacking attacks on your servers and computers.

https://trello.com/b/9I286Mhu/software-inc

Very cool game that has Steam Workshop and plenty of neat mods to add more things, but the vanilla version of the game is still packed with features. 

This is easily the best software tycoon management game on Steam. It's $14. It's made by one dude. Buy it.

I wann abe honest here, i bought this game on a whim.
To be completly honest, i bought Everspace and since my internet is not the best and the download took forever, i bought this game since i figured it was small.
I played games like these before and none of them really captured me. You reached the highest highs pretty fast ... there wasn't too much content. That is what i expected from this game that i bought as a tool to amuse me until my Download is ready.
i bought the game on September 19th 2017.
One day after that on the 20th i have 11 hours into Software inc and haven't even touched or started my other game.

i am really impressed by this game. It feels fresh and enjoyable. 

The Mainaspect is not even to make "money" in this game. It is more like managing your employees and building a good building while keeping up with technological advancements.
It offers really great depth. 
And the artstyle is charming.

Of course not everything is perfect.
The Tutorial is way to short. Everything will be explained but ... not really that much indepth. At least from the tutorials that pop up naturally.
I didn't know that i hade to seperate my different teams and make sure they don't run into each others rooms. 
Or how to label rooms for what they were.
But if you are okay with looking up some of the more detailed features and are willing to restart the game a few times over because of your failures, you will get a hidden gem with that one.

Found this game after fondly remembering Kairosoft's game called "Game Dev Story". I figured "If they could make a pretty awesome sim management game for phones, there should be PC equivalent somewhere." Lo and behold "Software Inc" is that game!

34968946.review:
Note 2+

Software Inc. ist eine super Simulation mit dem Schwerpunkt Wirtschaft. Ich habe bislang etwa 25 Std. investiert, und die haben sich in meinen Augen gelohnt. Bislang konnte ich keinerlei Fehler beim Spielen erkennen. 

Da dass Spiel sich aktuell in der Early Access befindet, werde ich dieses Review zur gegebener Zeit aktualisieren.

34968032.review:
Auf einmal hatten wir eine Vision als wir aufwachten. Wir haben unseren Lebenstraum gefunden. Wir wollen Chef eines Welt-Softwarekonzerns werden. Software aus allen Bereichen sollen auf dem Markt kommen, mit unserem eigenen Firmennamen drauf und sollen auf der ganzen Welt bekannt sein. Ein ambitioniertes Unterfangen mit unseren gerade mal 9000 Euro angespartem Geld aber hey - 1980, Aufschwung des Software-Markts. Los geht's!

So in etwa kann man Software Inc. zu Anfang beschreiben. Eine komplexe Wirtschaftssimulation, die ihren Schwerpunkt auf Software-Entwicklung fokussiert, mit vereinfachter aber stilistisch passender Spielgrafik.


[h1]Was gibt es zu tun?[/h1]​
Wir haben das Ziel. ein Weltkonzern zu erschaffen und beginnen wahlweise im Jahr 1980. Wir haben in den Standarteinstellungen wenig angespartes Geld und müssen das Beste daraus machen. Wir haben ein kleines leeres Grundstück, auf dem wir schnell einen flüchtigen Holzschuppen bauen. Möbel rein, natürlich auch den Computer und ein bisschen Grünzeug. Fertig ist die 2 mal 3 Felder große Bude. Wir können aber natürlich nicht direkt loslegen, denn Gute Software ist teuer und aufwendig. Um unser Budget aufzubessern, haben wir die Möglichkeit, ein paar Aufträge von netten Firmen zu erledigen, die selber zu faul oder zu geizig sind, ihre eigenen Leute dafür einzusetzen. Dafür gibt es ja uns. Je nach Charaktereinstellung, bewältigen wir diese Aufgaben gut oder weniger gut. Egal, jedenfalls bringt uns das ein gutes Startkapital ein. Schließlich müssen wir auch unsere ersten Mitarbeiter einstellen. Programmierer Designer Künstler und Vermarkter stehen uns zur Verfügung. Der Stellenmarkt gibt uns zufällige Leute, in die wir investieren können. Doch die Wahl sollte gut überlegt sein. Alles haben Schwerpunkte in denen sie gut sind und Punkte in denen sie ihre Inkompetenz zeigen. Je nach Projekt, das wir am Anfang beginnen wollen, müssen wir passende Mitarbeiter finden und natürlich auch brauchen wir Vermarkter. Werbung ist schließlich alles. 
Wenn wir dann unsere ersten hunderttausenden Euro gemacht haben (falls es gut läuft) können/ müssen wir unser Büro Vergrößern und mehr Mitarbeiter einstellen, um das benötigte know-how zu haben, um wiederum noch bessere Software zu entwickeln. So wird aus unserer kleine Bude, ein geräumiges Büro das wir in Sims-Manier zu einem kleinen Hochhaus ausbauen können, wenn wir wollen. Haben wir alles richtig gemacht, den Markt gut im Auge behalten, gut gewirtschaftet und richtige Entscheidungen getroffen, besitzen wir viele Milliarden Euro, hunderte von Mitarbeiter und Software die jeder Mensch auf der Welt nun kennt. Glückwunsch an euch. Ihr habt soeben den Status eines Bill Gates erreicht.


[h1]​Gameplay:[/h1]​
Software Inc. Spielt sich sehr gut allerdings wird man, das sage ich jetzt schon, erst mal viele male auf die Schnauze fallen, bevor die Kasse richtig klingelt. Das liegt nicht an Bugs, von denen ich keine nennenswerten entdecken konnte und auch nicht an der Balance, an der viel gearbeitet wird. Es liegt tatsächlich an all die Dinge, auf die wir aufpassen müssen. Am Umfang des Spiels. Am Anfang müssen wir Geld reinholen. Das heißt, Aufträge von Externen erledigen. Das Ganze läuft dabei so ab, wie mit allem in Software Inc. Sobald wir eine Software beginnen zu entwickeln, beginnt die Designphase, aus der Folgt dann der Kern einer jeden Software: Das Schreiben des Quellcodes und das Programmieren und verarbeiten von Grafiken, falls benötigt. Schlussendlich, kommt die letzte Phase. Eine Beta-Phase in der die Software auf Fehler getestet wird. Dann kommt die Veröffentlichung und Bestellmenge. Wir selber aber entscheiden, wie lange dies Phasen dauern sollen. Wir können jederzeit die Software aufwerten, mit den entsprechen Konsequenzen, wenn es zu früh war. Entwicklung braucht Zeit und Zeit ist Geld. So läuft das Prinzip von Software Inc. ab. 
Der andere Aspekt ist natürlich: Wie sieht der Markt aus? Welcher Softwaretyp gibt es nur wenig? Welche dominieren? Die Marktbeobachtung ist der Schlüssel zum Erfolg. Gute, auf dem Markt kaum vorhandene Software, verkauft sich extrem gut wenn die Qualität stimmt. Um das den Leuten in der Welt klar zu machen, ist es auch erforderlich viel Marketing zu betreiben. Nur so können wir eine Fanbase aufbauen, die sich vergrößert und auch auf unsere Software schlussendlich wartet. Zu guter Letzt, sind auch die Mitarbeiter wichtig, die Fähigkeiten und Bedürfnisse haben. Wir müssen darauf achten, dass die Mitarbeiter alle Bedürfnisse in unserem Büro erfüllen können und dass sie auch miteinander auskommen. Ein Unternehmen mit schlechten Betriebsklima, mag niemand und vermiest am Schluss jede Software.


[h1]​Umfang:[/h1]​
Software Inc. bietet uns eine ganze Reihe an Möglichkeiten, wie wir an unser Ziel kommen. Das Spiel bietet ein erstaunlich umfangreiches Bausystem das an Sims erinnert. Wir ziehen Wände, bauen Fenster, Türen rein, setzen Möbel. Dabei gibt es viel Auswahl und wie in Sims auch Objekte, die die Bedürfnisse unserer Mitarbeiter stillen. Alle anderen Features spielen sich in Menüs und Tabellen ab. Hauptaugenmerk ist dabei die Software-Gestaltung. Wir haben viele Software-Typen denen wir individuelle Features hinzufügen können. Je mehr es werden um so länger dauert die Entwicklung. Es gibt zudem ein Server-System, Team-Verwaltung, Mitarbeiterverwaltung, Aktien, Marketing, Wirtschaftsanalysen, Software-Verwaltung und noch einiges mehr. Es ist zudem möglich, ohne Probleme, sehr groß zu bauen und hunderte von Mitarbeiter zu haben, die Verwaltet werden müssen. Micromanagemet wird in dem Spiel großgeschrieben und bietet für sehr viel Stunden etwas zu tun.


[h1]​Grafik:[/h1]​
Die Grafik ist sehr einfach gehalten und doch ist der Stil der Grafik stimmig und passend. Objekte besitzen meist wenige Polygone und Texturen sind recht wenig vorhanden aber ein gut ausgestattetes Büro sieht wirtlich ansehnlich aus. FPS-Einbrüche, auf Grund der Größe der Büros oder der Anzahl der dargestellten Mitarbeiter sind mir nicht aufgefallen. Trotzdem scheint auch die vereinfachte Grafik, mehr Leistung zu brauchen, als eigentlich nötig. Da ist noch Optimierungsarbeit geragt.


[h1]​Sound:[/h1]​
Musik gibt es nicht wirklich und Sound auch nur minimal im Büro Gebäude. Es ist ein insgesamt stilles Spiel. Vielleicht kommt da in Zukunft noch mehr. Tipp: Musik nebenbei laufen lassen.


[h1]​Zusammengefasst:[/h1]​
Wem Game Dev Tycoon​ zu einfach oder zu wenig war, wird mit Software Inc. glücklich werden. Das Spiel gibt uns alle Freiheiten, die wir brauchen, um einen Weltkonzern auf die Beine zu stellen. Marketing, Mitarbeiter-Verwaltung, Aktien, Mark-Beobachtung, Software Entwicklung, Auflage drucken und so weiter, steht uns zur Verfügung. Die Herausforderung besteht darin nun, all diese Möglichkeiten geschickt anzuwenden. Klingt leicht, ist aber schwer. Software Inc. ist ein schweres Spiel und erfordert viele Anläufe, bis man das Prinzip wirklich durchschaut hat. Der Aufbau des Büros macht dabei sehr viel Spaß, sowie das Ausknobeln, wie man nun am meisten Profit machen kann​. 
Die Schwäche bei Software Inc. liegt in der Entwicklungsphase der Software. Das stupide reine abarbeiten, der einzelnen Entwicklungsphasen, ist langweilig und ein reines warten, bis man die Software hochstufen kann. Ich finde hier müssen die Entwickler etwas machen, damit auch diese Phase des Spiels, spaß macht. Auch die manchmal willkürlichen Ergebnisse sind merkwürdig. Mal verkauft sich eine Software super, manchmal nicht. Das Spiel reflektiert hier zu wenig die Gründe für solche Ergebnisse. 

Unterm Strich ist Software Inc. ein sehr unterhaltsames Spiel und erfüllt kleine Träume wie: Wenn ich Microsoft gegründet hätte, wie wäre ich vorgegangen? Was würde ich als Bill Gates tun? Ein Spiel also das auch die Fantasie zudem anregt. Von mir gibt es eine Kaufempfehlung, da auch die Entwickler ständig am Ball bleiben und es eine moderte Anzahl von sehr guten Mods gibt.

34963319.review:
Software Inc. is a great game. It's the kind of game where you can choose to do everything yourself, or you can choose to have your managers run your entire company and you can litterally just sit back and watch Fixer Upper or Doctor Who (Lol that's what I do)     

You can custom create your own company building, to be anyway you want, what's that? there's a furniture item you want but the game doesn't have it? 

Mod support.
This game has steam workshop!
So you can download blueprints for company buildings (for if you don't like building too much)
you can download more softwares (sometimes doing the same softwares over and over gets boring so mods can be great)
and furniture!
I went into the game's files and changed all the male character's first names to buttonwillow. It's actually very pleasing lol, like one time I saw a guy's name was Buttonwillow King.

You can really choose how much you want to actually manage the game.
You can set it so you only have to come check it once every hour or so.
You can set it so you really have to watch it the entire time if you want.

But overall, it can get kind of dull while waiting for softwares to be created.
So I reccomend you have something on the side to do, like sometimes I'll play Software Inc. while playing a second game (both games require little attention, so together it wasn't hard to do)
This is a very good game if you have something on the side to do, but it would be kind of boring over time if I didn't watch TV while playing it.

Overall, I DO reccomend it, but If you're not excited about the whole idea of it being a slow process,
you should probably really watch some videos of it before you buy it, or buy it on sale.
I check if a game I buy is worth it, the way I do so is every hour I play is worth $1. And if I play 15 hours, then the game is worth $15 to me. As I'm writing this review, I've got 83 hours played. Now this game is NOT worth 83 dollars, lol.
But it's definately worth it's price to me

34902761.review:
포텐셜 충분한 타이쿤 게임



장점

+ 발전 가능성
 추가할 컨텐츠가 잔뜩.

+ 타이쿤 게임으로서 충분한 복잡성 
 매니지먼트 요소 충분. 라이트 유저가 잡기엔 조금 부담스러울 수도.

+ 스타일 맞는 플레이어에게 어마어마한 몰입도
현실 노예코딩 하듯이 게임을 돌리는 수가 있음.

+ 저사양 및 깔끔한 디자인
저건 차고 저건 나무다 정도만 인식하면 끝나는 공돌이들에게 적합. 
차는 광택이 나야 하고 나무는 아름다워야 하는 미대생들에겐 부적합.

+ 샌드박스 스타일의 자유도
1인 제작자부터 Eat All 스타일 공장 운영까지 가능.
코딩 하청일로 신음하다 스트레스 받고 종료할 수도 있고, 마X크로소프트처럼 온갖 영역에 족적을 남길 수도 있다.

+ 단순화할 것은 잘라내고 살릴 부분은 잘 살리고
컨셉과 방향이 잘 잡혀있다고 볼 수 있다.

+ 모드 친화적
부족한 컨텐츠를 효과적으로 메꿈.




단점

- 아직 미완성이고 인디게임 특유의 느린 업데이트

- 단순한 그래픽
그래픽 보고 하는 게임은 아니지만, 부족한 부분은 상상력이 요구됨.
이 게임의 설계 방향은 딱 공대 수준.

- 알 듯하면서도 상식적으로 납득이 가지 않을 때도 있는 게임 내 소프트웨어 업계 
장인정신으로 한줄 한줄 짠 내 명품 프로그램이 경쟁사의 양산형 범작보다 덜 팔리는데 이유를 알 수 없는 경우.

- 타이쿤류 중에서도 숫자와 도표 비중이 높음
 하루종일 사무실에서 엑셀이랑 워드 만지고 와서 집에서 도표 보는 기분. 일과 놀이는 한 끗 차이인가.

- 초반은 너무 어렵고, 후반은 긴장감이 떨어짐 (덜 조절된 난이도)
20살의 빌 게이츠와 50살의 빌 게이츠의 차이.
시류를 잘 타서 윈도우나 스타크래프트 같은걸 히트시키면 이후는 경영게임이 아니라 컨셉플레이로 전환. 
그러지 못했다면 한평생 코딩 하청으로 먹고살다가 은퇴할 수도 있다.
리얼리즘을 잘 살렸으니 장점으로 봐야 할 수도.

- 소프트웨어 산업, 컴퓨터 산업 전반에 대한 지식이 있어야 온전히 즐길 수 있는 깊이
컴맹은 이 게임으로 고통받을 확률이 높다.




결론 :

돈값은 충분히 한다. 

남녀노소 즐길 수 있는 라이트한 게임은 아니다.

틀이 잘 잡혀 있으므로 지금 추세대로 완성하면 갓겜이 될 것 같은 포텐셜

34810099.review:
Alpha 9 is finally public! I never played the previous Alpha 8 version, only this one while on the testing branch, so I thought it only right that I wait before posting my own thoughts.

Considering that just one guy is making this, all on his lonesome, it's freaking amazing. IMO the dedication and attention to detail puts even some AAA games to shame... for an Early Access game this is remarkably stable, smooth-running and virtually bug-free, and updates are regular and hit the nail every time. Frankly, I consider this the best value-for-money I've ever spent on a game, any game, and I'm a long way from done just yet!

Even though very much pursuing his own vision, the dev has shown himself to be open to feedback and actually listens to what players have to say, which is a growing rarity in this day & age. Obviously he has to pick & choose from the multitude of suggestions and half-baked ideas, but I've even seen stuff just mentioned in a casual discussion between players actually appear in the game just days later... now THAT's a dev aiming to make the best game he can.

Is it perfect? No, it's still Early Access for a reason, but it's definitely heading in the right direction and the core gameplay is absolutely superb, [i]if you like that kinda thing[/i]. There's the rub: it plays as a pretty unique cross between The Sims, a building game, and a very detailed economic / business & logistics simulation. If you actually enjoy all of these aspects in your gaming then the chances are you will absolutely love this, but just about everyone else should at least get more than their money's worth and have some real fun doing so!

34496786.review:
自从文明、天际线系列之后，又一个 “下一阶段天亮了” 的游戏。

[h1] 还你一个游戏制作梦——[/h1]
给软件取名字太好玩了！

你可以选择游戏类型和各种功能，游戏中的好游戏制作时间会超过2年，开发周期长测试时间让你崩溃，所以你可以有选择性地选择。比如CG做得特别好，[spoiler] 是的我说的就是暴雪[/spoiler]，但是游戏不支持局域网不支持手柄之类的！就可以把制作时间压缩到一年啦，每次发布产品第二天新闻都会有测评，到底是个还okay的游戏还是能蝉联销售TOP？设计很关键！

[h1] 模拟建造——[/h1]
你可随便建造以装修设计自己的办公室。

随着时代推移可以更新电子设备，2000年笔记本电脑，2020年全息电脑[spoiler] （让员工拥有自己的办公室他们很开心，更换设备的时候你就不开心了）[/spoiler]程序、设计、艺术、市场分开办公室，把地砖和壁纸改成不同色调，在打开标注房间类型，你就可以很直观地看见不同职能的工作情况。后来我开了饭堂，请了几个师傅，装修成KFC的样子，红色的最廉价的塑料椅子[spoiler]吃完就快回去干活[/spoiler]，白色的饭桌上放了降压但减少工作效率的酒精饮料，我真是个好老板。另外在公司楼上做了个图书馆，图书馆隔壁有电脑室，一次也没见过有人来看书，伤心呐。

[h1] 模拟人生——[/h1]
如果…你不只是把员工当机器的话。

我玩到2000年，有个员工出生意外死了，是个艺术家，我不知道是什么意外，是不是办公室天太黑绊倒的，因为系统提示了几次，我都没去修，很内疚。

有的员工退休了，若干年后系统提示：XXX 变成小天使了 [spoiler] 去世了[/spoiler]

点开员工详情，你可以得到更多：）

建议：招人尽量招20+的，工作技能很快提升，性格和特长比较重要。每隔五年补充新人进来。
注意：每年的七月员工都会放暑假，游戏早期要注意，容易造成外包延误，要赔偿金。


· 如果新闻有个季度或者半年一年度的，像报纸头版或者杂志封面，随机放出活跃度最高的软件，销售最高的软件，会比较适合截图……
· 没有成就系统和steam卡牌

评分 8/10

34401953.review:
Grand fan de Game Dev Tycoon et Mad Game Tycoon, je m'attendais à vraiment aimer ce Sotware Inc qui s'annonçait bien plus complet. Et bien non, et pourtant j'ai essayé !

1) Il n'y a aucune aide. Les tutoriaux du début expliquent vaguement à quoi sert chaque panneau, mais ils sont buggués et concrètement on se retrouve à soit galérer comme jamais pour essayer de comprendre comment le jeu fonctionne, soit à se taper des interminables Let's Play pour apprendre à jouer.

2) L'interface est absolument affreuse, les menus sont remplis de tableaux austères en noir et blanc se ressemblant tous, il faut sans cesse scroller horizontalement pour accéder à toutes les informations.

3) C'est lent. Réaliste certes, mais vraiment lent. J'ai codé 2 OS, et j'ai passé les deux fois environ 20 à 30min à simplement attendre que les mois passent puisque le développement dure plusieurs années.

4) Il n'y a aucun sentiment de progression, on débloque vagument quelques options en plus au fil des années pour étoffer nos logiciels, mais aucune notification ne vient nous prévenir.

5) Plus globalement, ce jeu n'est vraiment pas ludique. Ca ne donne pas envie, ça manque de fun. Les noms des concurents et de leurs logiciels se ressemblent tous, on se retrouve à développer des softs qui se ressemblent tous, que ce soit "Mon OS 2" et "Mon logiciel Audio 3.0". Il manque une âme à ce jeu.

Attention je ne dis pas que Software Inc est un mauvais jeu, je dis simplement qu'il ne m'a vraiment pas plu.

34358945.review: Software Inc is a superbly detailed simulator of excellent quality, depth, replayability and entetainment value. It's instantly clear that the developer poured his heart into this game. This game flawlessly blends the builder, software and sims genres. Software Inc leaps beyond the compeition. There's no arbitrary sliders or component micromanagement as seen in other games in the software/game development genre, but there's still plenty for the player to do. From designing, decorating and upgrading facilities, to choosing contracts to fulfill, parameters for developmet of software, pricing of that software, hiring the employees with the right personality traits and skills, building and managing teams, hiring staff to maintain your facilities, managing utility expenses, advertising, research, patenting, buying out competitors, ensuring your software and pricing is competitive, choosing distributors, becoming a distributor yourself, and much more. The other games of this genre are so basic as to seem as though they belong in arcades by comparison. You've been playing phone aps. This is a simultator build for a computer.

34345489.review:
This game is in pre-release, but god damn is it very playable.

It is addicting. It invokes the same drive that Civilization games instill in me. You just want to go for one more month, one more development cycle. Oh what software should I make? Who should I hire? What sort of skills do I need in my company? How should I divide my labour into teams? Do I have enough money to even to do this? Should I take time away from developing my next project to research and patent a technology? If I don't then another company will get it and I will have to pay them a royalty to use it. Or I could just buy the patent from them. Or just buy their company outright via the stock market.

These are just some of the choices you will be making in the game. From financial and technical decisons to the nitty-gritty administrative details of how your firm is run. 

Thouroughly recommend that you buy this game now as I want to see the full scale release as soon as possible. It is only developed by a single coder and the more money we give him, the more the developer will be encouraged to work.

34303574.review:
----- My Review was based on the Alpha 8 ---------

This is game at first glance for me wasn't much to look at, and indeed when I first started to play it I didn't like it. 

However after giving it a few days to play another game similar to this, I thought I would give this another go. Well I have to admit after getting to grips with it from the start, I started to get into it really quick. 

Yes the graphics aren't what I expected, but the gameplay is brilliant. The amount of projects that you can build/create is huge. At first I perhaps expected great amounts of capital to be gained easily, rather too easily. However that isn't the case with certain products, largely down to your employees and your management of them. 

What attracts me the most is the fact that you're able to expand your business in a way that is both great and intruiging. Great because you make lots of capital so that you may indeed expand the business, intruiging because there is no end as to what type of building you can create in order to expand your business. And it is this aspect that draws me into this game because I'm sort of addicted to it. The stock market addition is a great idea that certainly comes in handy early on within the game, because you can make huge amounts of money with the right investments!

It has a small Modding community that comes in handy to help the game become better, even though the vanilla is pretty good in itself, but there's no harm in trying to improve it. 

                     ----- My Review was based on the Alpha 8 ---------

BEWARE:- If you're thinking of getting this, ALPHA 9 is much more difficult than ALPHA 8. Progress bar has been taken from the alpha phase of projects. More difficult to know what is required at alpha phase than it were in ALPHA 8. The marketing is much more difficult too and imo too much of a chore. If I wanted to work instead of playing then I would play this all day in ALPHA 9, because that's what it feels like to me and NOT a game anymore. I wish the DEVS would look into this and at least help and make it more user friendly again like they did in ALPHA 8. Otherwise I don't see the point anymore wasting my time getting frustrated because the game feels like a damn chore now in ALPHA 9...And it is this reason that I've NOW given this game a NOT RECOMMENDED

Overall a great experience. It was very satisfying to grow from a one-man team, micromanaging projects and contract work, into a software mogul, keeping check on team effectiveness and expanding into other markets. The good:
- Systems felt fair and balanced overall
- Graphics look good
- Lots of fun if you're into tychoon type games

The bad:
- Tutorials could use some work to be more fun and engaging
- Some interior decoration features felt clunky, for example the fact that you cannot create rooms within rooms
- Could use some more late-game mechanics to make it more fun when the business has grown big

Looking forward to checking out the mods!

34130590.review:
If your aren't already convinced by the wealth of positive reviews then this won't do much more, but I want to jump on the positive review train to give this game some extra love, because it definitely deserves it!

What makes this game stand out is the detail.  You get a significant level control over your company, from high level strategy and approach down to which month a particular employee gets to go on holiday.  The level of control can seem daunting at first, but there are helpful tutorials in game and out, and once you have the basics down the mechanics provide a lot of freedom for the direction in which you would like to go.  The graphics are simple, but the style is effective, and with this comes a low load on performance requirements meaning accessibility for older or lower powered systems is almost a guarantee!

With a one man development team it does mean that stable updated can be slow going, but the developer regular releases his testing branch work via Steam betas, and is always keen to listen and learn from players.  Communication is good, and players are rarely left in the dark about any near or planned developments, as the developer is always excited to share new ideas and clearly passionate about the project.

What this means is a great project, at a more than good price tag, great fun to play now, and a lot of exciting developments coming in the near future!!

TL;DR - 
Fulfilling and enjoyable experience, with an excellent dev, absolutely worthy of support!

33978299.review:
This is one of the deepest and most rewarding tycoon games that I have ever played. Unlike some other tycoon games that where fun such as planet coaster, this made you think about the business side of your company. I will admit that it took me a while to pick up on most of the finer details of the game (I would say about 20 hours or me figuring it out to really get good at it), but what kept me going and playing this game even though I was struggling and at the start not having much fun, was the fact that I saw the depth and potential of this title; I am very glad I stuck with it.  There are still several things that need to be polished or flushed-out, but even in its current state if you want a deeper tycoon game, then pick up this title.
Some tips: Just because your character is good at development (let's say 2D), he is not good at developing anything that is not his specialty (like audio). I assumed (wrongly) that if your character was strong in development he got a boost in the one you chose and a slight penalty in the others, not so. Albeit I think if you can design 3D in real life, that most of your skills would carry over to 2D, this game treats one like learning math, and one like learning English (just because you improve in one does not affect the other). Also managing team size is very important as 10 people working on a project might be less productive than a 2-man team. 
Things the game needs to improve: wall placement tool is sometimes wonky and annoying. The stock market portion does not feel fleshed out. I also want set number of companies, it seems that if there are <21 companies the game just generates a new one. I want to buy up all the companies, or have some kind of end game.  For contract/deals I want to be able to issue them. For example, if I make an OS, I was to be able to go to another company and say hey for $x I will pay you to port your program to my OS, or make it exclusive to my OS, things that you do in real life. I also think the distribution system is still too wonky as the workload is high and you make no money, it is a loss leader from my experience. Also like most tycoon games, once you hit your rhythm it start to just snow ball, you struggle to make a million, then you explode to 5 million, then all of the sudden you are 50 million, and in the blink of an eye you are 200+ million.

33916392.review:
Finally an early access game I don't regret

Other than some titles that feel like playable tech demos without actual game behind it, this one I enjoyed. I would really like for the devs to not add more features but to flesh out things that are already there. And I cannot stress enough that I did not experience a single crash or other hiccup during 50 hours of play (!!), but I also think the gameplay is unbalanced and ultimately not challenging at all.

Features
+ The core (building, forming teams, defining products, watch their progress) is fun!
+ You really feel like a software developer
- Hosting and defining different server farms is cool, but as of now not interesting. There are no impactul events like outages or spikes, total failures that ruin your work if you didnt plan for it. Have enough and forget about it.
- Distribution channels, insurance, company takeovers are clearly unfinished. Either the devs find a fun and meaningful way to include them or they should scrap them and focus on other things.

UI
+ Cloning tool work great, so building a multi-storey office is quite easy 
+ Wall clock shows actual ingame time ;-)
+ I like the programming "animation". Looks legit
0 Graphic quality is okay for this type of game 
- The game often does not provide the information I want 
      * Are Development taks assigned to SCM
      * How well does an employee fit into teams (without assigning them first)
      * How much does a team member contribute to the progress?
      * How big an impact does the furniture/his skills/ actually have?
      * Why does a product not sell?
- Or is cumbersome to use
      * Porting multiple products to other OS
      * Scrolling in lists to pick the correct team


Gameplay / Balancing - This might need the most work! (Played on hard btw)
- Outstanding quality products with every single feature in the book sell only a few copies, while the good game with only two features rakes in millions. It seems to only depend on your overall standing in that market segment
- 3D-Editors eventually sell to millions of customers grossing half a billion $ easily and while OS usually don't attract much customers, if they do that sort of ends the game. You can overtake all competitors within DAYS
- Competitors spamming the market with OS, yet its unclear what attracts customers to a specific OS. It's not a unique buquet of top notch software not available on other OS. Tried it.
- Full blown marketing offensive on all channels costs 6k + salaries ....
- Competitors pay you by the month to develop their stuff, so you are incentivies to keep finished work around till the last mont
- Customer decisions overall totally unclear. There are not multiple products with different features - Every product has every feature and of them has all the customers.
