29238767.review: Software Inc. seems like an interesting mix of the Sims (needs are not overly intricate, fortunately) and Game Dev Tycoon. I found it quite addicting, even in its early alpha state (beware parking lot traffic graphical glitches). If you want to optimize early game on normal or harder, you have a bit of learning curve to get through so expect a couple playthroughs to figure out how to optimize early game and some of the optimization mechanics like team compatibility bonuses and minimizing movement to get food or placing doors close to where people park their cars/get off the bus. I still haven't figured out how to prevent staff from becoming 'stressed out', especially leaders. Minigames are not required, but you will want to take advantage if you want to min/max and get your first billion dollars within the first 3 years or so. Stock market seems a bit off since if you buy any decently priced stocks, you won't be able to sell them for anywhere near the price you bought them for, even if their 'value' has gone up. My hint is develop software that uses a novel feature ASAP once it becomes unlocked, especially new software (e.g. make an OS with 3D rendering followed by a 3D Editor; or make an antivirus when it first appears).

29236136.review:
Softare inc to połączenie game dev tycoona, simsów i jakiejś gry o zarządzaniu (dużo tabelek), jest to gra w której zaczynamy od małego jednoosobowego przedsiębiorstwa, a kończymy na byciu monopolistą w świecie produkowania wszelkiego rodzaju oprogramowania, od systemu operacyjnego, poprzez gry, aż kończąc antywirusy.

Jak na wczesny dostęp gra zazwyczaj jest rozwijana bardzo szybko. Ostatnio autor stwierdził, że zamiast dodawać nowe rzeczy będzie zajmował się czasochłonnymi poprawkami wydajności i naprawami bugów, dlatego od marca 2017 roku gra jest rozwijana bardzo powoli i rzeczy które były zazwyczaj dodawane w tydzień, teraz są dodawane w miesiąc. Ja osobiście dużo błędów nie spotykam, ale jeżeli już jakiś to z systemem budowania, albo z jakimś przypadkowym crashem. Drobne problemy z balansem są zazwyczaj naprawiane błyskawicznie. Sam twórca gry bardzo aktywnie wypowiada się na forum steam, słucha się fanów i poprawia najbardziej dokuczliwe elementy. Recenzuje grę gdy jest w wersji Alpha 9.10, standardowo gdy kupi się grę instaluje się alpha 8, ale w ustawieniach steama można ustawić wersje testową podpisaną chyba [testing], można także wrócić do starszej wersji niż standardowa (alpha 7), trzeba pamiętać że stany zapisów z tych gier nie są kompatybilne dla różnych wersji alph, dlatego jeżeli zaczniecie grać na standardowej i znacznie gorszej alphie 8 to nie będziecie mogli przenieść zapisu do alphy 9, pozostaje wam tylko nowa gra.

Software inc to gra wyjątkowa pod wieloma względami, autor gry (jest tylko jeden) zajmuje się dopieszczaniem drobnych aspektów gry, dzięki czemu całkowicie miażdży te wszystkie "tycoony" bawiące się w przesuwanie trzech pasków. Tutaj trzeba zająć się gigantyczną ilością rzeczy. 

Zaczne od budowy dobrego biura naszej docelowej korporacji, gdzie trzeba pomyśleć o gigantycznej ilości rzeczy (m.in. hałas, temperatura, oświetlenie, dostęp do wody i jedzenia, toaleta). Trzeba także zatrudniać personel żeby nasz sprzęt się nie zepsuł a podłoga nie była zbyt brudna (inaczej pracownicy będą często "chorować").

Sama ilość sposobów na zdobywanie pieniędzy jest dosyć spora. Nie trzeba ograniczać się do produkcji gier. Na samym początku mamy mało pieniędzy przez co najlepiej być firmą b2b. Możemy także założyć własną serwerownie i "drukarnie" opakowań do programów (płyt cd).

Najwięcej pieniędzy oczywiście przychodzi z tworzenia programów. Tutaj gracz musi uważać na konkurencje, ustalić odpowiednią cene, date wydania, zająć się marketingiem i wieloma innymi rzeczami. Tutaj też musze wspomnieć o beznadziejnym systemie "projektowania" tych programów. Jedyne co robimy to przed rozpoczęciem produkcji zaczynamy wybierać cechy naszego produktu, jest ich sporo ale to nie ma znaczenia, najlepiej bezmyślnie wybrać wszystkie możliwe, zawsze działa. Dodatkowo gra podaje nam od razu wiele rzeczy, np. ile powinno być pracowników z danej kategorii przy produkcji oraz ile mamy klepać program żeby stał się idealny. Całkowite zero myślenia, przez tę syfną mechanike software inc staje się zwykłym, monotonnym oglądaczem tabelek z czasem jak gramy. Autor zamierza to poprawić i podał już ciekawy projekt, natomiast kiedy to zrobi, nie wiem. Przez bardzo długi czas gra siedzi w alphie 9 i żadnych nowych rzeczy nie widziałem od bardzo dawna, obecnie głównie są naprawiane małe błędy.

Oczywiście ktoś te programy musi tworzyć, dlatego trzeba mieć odpowiednie zespoły mające swoje potrzeby, cechy charakteru i umiejętności. Wraz ze wzrostem firmy gra zaczyna się robić problematycznym klikaczem, dlatego są opcje automatyzacji zespołów i samej produkcji (co te zespoły mają produkować wybieramy sami, one zajmują się samym procesem tworzenia od zera do wydania, akurat "wymyślanie produktów" zjechałem wyżej).

Gra ma tragiczny GUI, jest on mało czytelny, trudny do opanowania dla nowego użytkownika oraz niespójny, są tutoriale ale są stworzone na podstawie złego GUI przez co niewiele pomagają. Warto też pamiętać, że gra posiada szczątkowy i przeciętny soundtrack włączający się tylko czasami, natomiast dźwięki otoczenia są takie jakie powinny być.

Graficznie i optymalizacyjnie nie jest źle. Gra obecnie zawiera benchmark, który automatycznie ustawi ci opcje. Ogółem powinno pójść na jakimś intel hd graphics w niskiej rozdzielczości, ale jest tak dużo opcji, że nawet gtx 1080ti gra wymęczy. Ja posiadam gtx 970 i i5 4590, gra sugeruje ustawienie medium i na dosyć podobnych gram. Minimalne wymagania są lekko przekłamane, to jest bardziej to co autor chce żeby było minimalnymi wymaganiami, obecnie gra pochłania gigantyczne ilości ramu, 8 gb wciąga bez problemów. Prawda jest taka, że gra jest bardzo zaawansowaną symulacją i po prostu musi trochę wymagać, mimo prostej grafiki.

Największym minusem gry jest poziom trudności - gra jest banalnie prosta i ma słabo zbalansowany system ekonomiczny. Polecam zacząć od razu grać na medium i gdy już się troche tę gre ogarnie przejść na hard. Ja zbankrutowałem jeden raz zanim nauczyłem się jak w to grać, ale są osoby które nie miały okazji przechodzić przez ten etap w ogóle.

Grę ogółem polecam, nie jest idealna i raczej taka nigdy nie będzie. Teoretycznie autor zapowiedział, że będzie grę rozwijać we wczesnym dostępie do 2018 roku, ale przy obecnym stanie rozwoju ja tego nie widzę, wciąż jest bardzo dużo rzeczy do zrobienia jak na przykład zarządzanie firmami które się wykupiło, tworzenie dodatków, growy kickstarter, zmiana ceny produktu po premierze i wiele innych. Gra obecnie jest bardzo fajnym i oryginalnym pomysłem z rozgrywką niezłego tycoona, po alphie 10 prawdopodobnie (w sensie jeżeli autor nie postanowi przeżucić zapowiadanych nowości na późniejszy termin) będzie już w miare składną produkcją, a po alphie 11 będzie to produkt wymagający już tylko dodatków usprawniających grę i ogółem poprawek balansu.

29217017.review:
This game sucked me in quickly. Got addicted fast. Made lots of software, and billions of dollars. Built out software dev teams and office space. Hired a bunch of people and spent a lot of time staring at menus trying to max out their abilities.

After making a huge pile of money I got bored with the game fast. Also it reminded me too much of work at times.

Needs more content. Could use more variation in what the people do on screen when milling about the office. More variation in office furniture. 

I found myself just sitting there staring at the screen for huge amounts of time at certain points just waiting compared to other games like this, so I would have appreciated more variation in what to look at.

Also, no music, which I found weird. Thought something was wrong with sound, but I just don't think there is much sound.

There is a lot of potential here. I had a lot of fun with this game. Worth it for the price, and I'll probably play it again at some point, maybe if a new update looks like it adds a bunch of stuff.

29216800.review: The best software dev simulation game I've played.

29194203.review:
+ Gameplay
+ Replayability
+ Building/Office Design
+ Realism
+ Developer
+ Stability
+ Peer Game Comparison
+ Procedurally Generated Worlds
+/- Learning Curve
+/- Graphics
+/- Sound
+/- Difficulty
+/- Interface
+/- Modability
+/- Optimization
- Music
- Campaign

I will mark whether I like something +, dislike something -, or am neutral +/- as I write the review.

You start as the founder of a software company in a standard sandbox enviroment +/-. You can choose the difficulty, speed of gameplay, starting funds, starting time period, traits, and skills of your founder +. You are able to set a basic appearance for the founder, but this is clearly not a focus of the game +/-. 

You cannot customize the size/capabilities of the competition outside of the basic difficulty selector -. This games does not simulate real companies and products, but it does realistic simulate technical progress +/-. That means you won't find Microsoft or Valve in the game. On the plus side, this means the market is unique to each playthrough, vastly improving replayability +.  

Once you set up your world, the game will simulate a number of years before your start date. This creates a background market (operating systems and some other various basic programs are already on the market) in the game...the software industry does not spring out of nowhere +. 

You start off by designing your office which can be a challenge in your first game +/-. The building interface is reminiscent of the Sims and is very intuitive and the interface flags things that you might have forgotten (temperature control, for instance). The office is fully 3D, and you can make very impressive multi-level structures +. Because of the time dilation, office optimization is much more important in this game than in real life (takes a lot longer for an employee to get somewhere than in real life) -, but that is par for the entire tycoon genre +/-. 

You make profit generally by releasing software or doing contract work for other companies. The game accounts for personnel management and some basic asset handling (insurance, your stocks, pension, investment in other companies, and your distribution vector). This kind of stuff is information heavy and marks it as a more serious management game compared to a casual simulation (which is a + for me). 

The nuts and bolts of the game is in balancing your cash flow so that you can produce software in a timely manner but also somehow pay for your employees in the mean time. This appears to be an accurate portrayal of the industry from an outsider's perspective (I am a banker, not a tech company developer in real life) +.

Personnel management is well developed. Employees are individualized with looks, traits and compatability. They can be assigned to teams, request raises, get sick, come in late and go to training/education +, There is an HR level in the game that can be automated which means hiring/firing/assignment/raises etc can be delegated to in-game employees. The same exists for project leads which allows you to scale your business to the dozens or potentially hundreds of employees and not be -as- bogged down in micromanagement +.  

There is a basic R&D component in the game, centering around patents +/-. The implementation at this point is not very good -, but it is a new feature at the time of this review. Otherwise, tech progress is a function the game year and not otherwise controllable. At this time, research is not a major part of the gameplay -.

There is a large selection of software types and the 'features' that make them up. The more features, the more powerful the product, but the more time it takes to develop. Software Inc. does a very good job in tying together the various kinds of software you develop together +. For example, you use your visual and audio editors (or license another company's) as well as a game engine to produce a game. This is quite natural and lets you enjoy intermediate products (editors, for instance) as well as the more well-known end-user ones (games, etc.) +.

Marketing exists in Software Inc., but only in a basic fashion. You can choose your vector (internet, radio, etc.) and simply pour money and manpower into it +/-. This is being fleshed out to include timing releases with marketing in the next update +. There is a similar gameplay depth in running servers and your own (abstracted) store. In the next update, physical distribution (printing your software onto media to be shipped out) is also being added to the game.

The difficulty curve is inverted. It is quite difficult in the beginning and becomes easier +/-. While this is similar to reality, games tend to avoid this. It is too cheap to scale your company -. After your breakthrough release, the game is easy -. The other gameplay scales fairly well and plays interestingly at both the one-person company level to the I don't know the names of all of my employees level +. 

The structural and world graphics are nice enough for this level of game +/-, but are not comparable to larger budget sims (Planet Coaster for instance). In particular, character models and animation are still quite weak -, but they've improved significantly recently +. There is a feature to save layouts for buildings in game, which is a massive + for replayability (if you don't want a unique office in every game), and there is a function for copying individual rooms if you want to copy/paste standardized designs in your structure(s).

Software Inc. supports mods and the workshop +. Because the gameplay design is in flux, gameplay mods are usually broken and the community is small -. Most 'mods' are office designs -.

Sound quality in the game is not memorable +/-. If there is music (and I don't think there is), I can't remember it at all, even after a lot of hours -. Audio production is clearly not a goal for this game which is reasonable for the genre +/-.

It is very bug-free for an EA title, but bugs do exist. Stability is no concern in this game +. Because it is developed on Unity, it is not ever going to be greatly optimized -, but the current state of optimization is sufficient for its scope +/-. It is too heavy for its weight, but that doesn't make it a heavyweight game, so to speak +/-.

There is no tutorial/campaign mode -. It is pure sandbox, so if you are expecting a narrative or progressive objectives (do this, do that!), this is not the game for you. I never play the campaigns in tycoon type games myself, so this isn't a concern +/-. No campaign means you are thrust into the thick of it, relying on the interface to teach you the game -. It wasn't a big problem for me, but for players who are not genre-savvy, it could be a concern +/-. 

This is an EA game run by a single developer made on Unity. Be aware of this if you buy this game +/-. That said, the developer is both industrious and transparent (has a public development Trello). In other words, you don't need to trust the developer. You can check on his progress at any time and make your own judgment. Because of these traits, I have great faith in the developer +. Just Google Trello and Software Inc. if you want to check it.

At this point, the developer could release the game and abandon it and would be a decent game that I would recommend +, and in its current state can give many players a good cost/hour ratio. This is a safe purchase in that sense +.

Software Inc. is a good game. It shines as an example of a successful single-dev EA game. However, the genre has weak competition and is not well developed. There are some game development simulators out there, and I enjoyed Mad Games Tycoon, but it is a different class of game. Software Inc. feels and plays like a PC game. The other ones feel and play like console/mobile games, if you understand my comparison. If you want a more streamlined, casual/arcadey simulator, this may not be the game for you. Software Inc. is more akin to Football Manager in a genre full of FIFAs (+ for me).

28964909.review: Software Inc. is a wonderful game. However, it does have some faults, just like everything other game. This is the perfect game for you if you're looking for a tycoon or simulator game. There is plenty of fun to be had in Software Inc. For the first few saves, this game wasvery difficult, as I had no strategies or knowledge about the game. After time, though, Software Inc. became very easy for me. I know just what to do when starting off and can now be successful in about a half hour. The game does take some skill. For the time I have played, I have enjoyed this game. This is not a game you could play for weeks and not get bored. There's just not enough content yet, making the game wear out quickly. There's only so much to do with the content available as of now. I do like the addition of mods, but that can also get boring fairly quickly. I am looking forward to the future updates to expand this game, and I am happy with what they have done so far. In conclusion, I would reccomend this game for anyone who likes tycoon and simulation games.

28934478.review:
Possibly one of the best tycoon games ever made, it gives you so much info to work with and simulates markets in extreme detail behind the scenes. So you're actually facing a realistic challenge as you try to grow your one-person startup into a multi-team company that sells multiple products.
The feeling of going from a making a measley $10k a month doing outsourced contracts for other companies to building a software empire that rolls over $50,000,000 a month with 10 different teams working on 10 different projects and the hurdles that come along the way is amazing. Again, possibly the best tycoon game I've ever played.
A major example of a big hump along the road in my company was that I took on a software printing contract for another company. I didn't realize I didn't have the print capacity to print all of the copies, so when the due date came, I was 4 million copies short. I went from $8,000,000 in the bank to bankrupt overnight. Made me appreciate the depth and detail of the game even more, provides a real and actual challenge.
And the best part is that it can only get better because its in early access.

28307818.review:
Dieses Spiel hat einen eigenen Charme und ist an sich ein gutes, sehr komplexes Game, was einem eine Menge Zeit abverlangt, da durchzusteigen. Im Prinzip also für Lerneifrige sehr zu empfehlen. Man kann Aufträge erfüllen, Spiele und andere Software erstellen und verkaufen, Management betreiben und jede Menge bauen. Alles Super! Wenn da nicht die Warte- und Klickorgien wären ( z. B. bei der Erfüllung von Aufträgen). Hier ist man nämlich gezwungen, den Stop-Button im Auge zu behalten um den Moment des kurzen roten Aufleuchtens des Selbigen nicht zu verpasen. Denn genau in diesem Moment muss man darauf klicken, um die nächste Stufe des Auftrages zu erreichen. Verpasst man den Moment nämlich, dann wird die Software, die man gerade erstellt hat, buggy und man verliert Zeit und Geld. Diese alberne Geschicklichkeits- und Geduldstests wiederholen sich ständig und nerven gewaltig. Da wäre eine Checkbox in den Optionen schön um diesen Schnulli auszuschalten. 
Auch gehen dauernd und in viel zu kurzen Abständen irgendwelche Geräte kaputt. Diese müssen dann durch teures Personal repariert werden. Das Geld kann man sich aber "glücklicherweise" durch mehrfaches Geschicklichkeitsklicken zurückverdienen. 
Software Inc. ist kein schlechtes Spiel und sicher besser als die meisten seiner Art, wenn dieser Warte-auf-das-rote-Licht-Gedulds-Reaktionszeit-Klickmist nicht wäre...

28244550.review:
Worth the price even in Early Access. Very sofisticated and ready-to-play game already. I spent the first 3 hours in just building the office without even spending a game day. This game offers even more options in building than The Sims. 

Ran the game in blackground because all my teams are on automatic. Come back to realized my legendary founder of the company has retired.

10/10 would macro-manage teams again.

28242882.review:
[h1]One of the most addictive sims I've ever played[/h1]

Software Inc. is a [i]fantastic[/i], micro-managing, worker/ company sim. I cannot even hazard a guess as to how much more amazing this game will be once released from EA. I purchased this 02.12 and have happily spent nearly 30 hours playing thus far. Judging by the discussions, patch notes and reviews, Coredumping is totally committed in spinning out a truly polished game. Folks, [b]THIS[/b] is Early Access used properly.

I'm a multitudinous genre gamer and, hands-down, Software Inc. is currently feeding the sim monster inside me. This game meets all my expectations in a sim and so much more: it's challenging, [b]complex[/b], customise-able, mature, and rewarding; it's a true pleasure to see my company and all its busy bees thrive against the competition. The content and detailed game-play currently available is, I feel, quite adequate. There is user-added content in Steam's Workshop for those who can't wait for more, or want something a little extra now. 

The graphics and colour palette are aesthetically pleasing; mechanics are fluid, AI is smart, and the tutorial--[i]a must![/i]--is straightforward and helpful. If I've encountered any bugs, I never noticed them.

If you like micro-managing sim games, worker-dictation and/ or company building, you are truly in for a treat, adding Software Inc. to your games library. The listed price (13,99€ as of 07.12.2016) is certainly justified.

[b]10/10[/b]
[i]*I'll update this review post-EA[/i]

26174267.review:
I'm not going to lie, about 60% of the reason I bought this game was because it was late and the trailer had nice 8-bit music. 
That said, I'm glad I did! This game is solid overall, and there is a healthy enough modding community that's managed to add a surprisingly large amount of content for such a small (devteam-wise) game. 
Which, I suppose, is the reason for some of the biggest flaws here: the UI is in general somewhat lacking (it's eminently usable, and that's the most that could be said for it). The sound design, as well, is lacking: the only sounds you'll hear are wind from outside (in the tundra at least), typing noises, cars, etc. Overall a very lacking soundscape, but if you want to play music or a podcast over it you will miss literally nothing.
Overall, though, a very nice little game, that some have found a lot of joy from!

26169467.review:
TL;DR - Great little indie game if you are interested in running a software company, simulation games and/or just like to geek out on building a nice little (or huge for that matter) office. Not for the more action- or graphics oriented gamer and not too much of a challenge to be had (if you're decent at simulation games that is :P).

[h1] What is the game about? [/h1]
This is a great example of one of those little gems out there made by indie developers. Software Inc. currently already has quite enough options and variety in what is essentially a sandbox game. With the basic starting settings you begin with a few thousand bucks and the tools to use those to build yourself a tiny room/garage with a table and computer. Your ingame avatar then starts hammering at his keyboard alternating between developing new software titles and doing some contract work, because the latter pays a lot more bills at the start. It's impossible to compete against the pre-existing companies out there at that moment. You start getting some consumer recognition, improve your skills, hire some employees and proceed to take over the (entire?) software market if done right. You do this by out-earning your competitors and buying all of their stock and do a hostile takeover (netting you their intellectual properties along the way). It's fun, can be quite engrossing (with a bit of roleplay, because otherwise it's all just managing sliders and figures) and is worth it's current € 14 (or regional equivalent) pricetag. Is it perfect? No, not quite. Here's a breakdown of what I consider the game's good, bad and noteworthy 'neutral' characteristics:

[h1] The good: [/h1]
[list]
[*][b]It's a proper simulated sandbox game:[/b] meaning that there is no handholding and the game simply has a set of rules that will net you a win if understood and exploited properly. For instance, it's important to note what (kind of) software you release. If you release a few decent virus scanners the consumer will notice and your "fans" will increase future interest, sales and thus profit of another released virus scanner. Not so much if you change tack and decide to release a first person shooter instead. It might still do ok, but nobody figured that your company "Kapsersky" would release a decent game. Makes sense, right? Other companies don't sit still either and will constantly develop new software. Looking at the "upcoming releases" it's important not to time your small company's anti-virus release with "Bug Squasher 6" made by the current dominant force in the game. There's more examples -and- there probably is more pseudo-simulation going on than is apparently noticeable, but it feels involved and complex enough and not like you're being railroaded from a garage to a medium office to a captain of industry.
[*][b]The building and office customization you can do is well done:[/b] the game offers a fairly powerful and easy to use build mode a la the Sims where you can go crazy in building the office you like (of course constrained by your current budget). [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/voeter/screenshot/428232315148646337]Here[/url] is my first playthrough attempt of a software company office. You can customise the building exterior, interior, flooring, colours and of course the furniture. The only downside here (that will hopefully improve over time) is a limited selection of placeable furniture. [b]edit[/b] After looking at the workshop, there apparently are already a load of mods out there that add a -lot- of extra furniture to play with. If you have an interest in decorating your office I recommend you check them out! [b]/edit[/b]
[/list]

[h1] The bad: [/h1]
[list]
[*][b]Lack of a challenge, especially mid-/lategame:[/b] Once you get past the first start-up hurdle it seems pretty much impossible to lose the game. At the start I guess you -could- lose by refusing to take contracts (that will easily net you enough money for ingame years of fiddling around with software development) and/or going crazy and hiring a bunch of employees you cannot afford, but other than that I've never felt -any- pressure to perform so I won't lose/go bankrupt/get bought out by the AI (if the latter is even possible). I'm hoping/kind of expecting this to change as the game develops further though.
[/list]

[h1] The noteworthy neutral: [/h1]
[list]
[*]The graphics: The game isn't exactly built on the cryengine. It looks fairly basic (as you can see from the screenshots) but in my opinion does have it's charm. When you have customised your own office, zoom out a bit and look at it through cloudy skies I kind of like it. Your employees hammering away at their keyboards with outstretched arms when coding their next masterpiece is fun to see too. On the upside, although not the best looker the visual part of the engine is coded well and gives me an excellent framerate all the time. There's lots of similar "meh"-looking games out there that for some reason tank your fps to slideshow speed with too many actors on the screen, lots of lighting to be rendered, when going into build mode, etc. Never the case for me with this game
[*][b]Limited replayability(?):[/b] After about 15 hours I nearly finished my first playthough. I expect to buy out every competitor in about an hour or so more of churning out my top of the market programmes. I'll probably start over once more and try a different approach/specialisation in certain softwares but that'll be it for me. I'm not really that interested in creating huge works of architecture or 'winning' even faster by building an office 10-20-50x the one I have now and managing dozens of projects at the same time. I like to play sims to enjoy the simulation, the associated emergent gameplay and to basically -not lose-. Considering I've pretty much seen (and enjoyed) the first two and the not losing part isn't really relevant I hope future additions, changes and/or mods will help in the future :) As for you reading this review, if you got this far, I hope my bit of insight helps you to consider if this is an issue for you or not.
[/list]

26098378.review:
In diesem Genre eine echte Perle!

Über die Optik kann man vielleicht noch streiten, aber was gameplaytechnisch in diesem Spiel steckt, lässt sich nicht abstreiten!

Diese Simulation ermöglicht es, eine Software-Firma aufzubauen. Und ja, das Geschäftsgebäude zu bauen und zu erweitern und auch Computer und Server nach gegebener Zeit durch bessere zu ersetzen, gehört ebenfalls dazu. Bereits hier muss schon auf Dinge wie Ventilation und Lärmbelästigung geachtet werden. Verhält sich insgesamt ein bisschen wie Sims, mit einer Prise mehr Realismus.

Danach gehts ans Eingemachte, nämlich dem Programmieren. Von Anti-Viren-Software, zu Spielen, Sound-Tools, Grafik-Programme und vielem mehr, lässt sich hier alles programmieren; und auch zu Geld machen. Oder auch nicht? Denn so einfach ist das nicht. Software Inc. bietet sehr viel Spieltiefe. Jede Kleinigkeit lässt sich kontrollieren und regulieren, eine echte Management-Herausforderung. Darauf zu achten, dass nichts aus dem Lot gerät, wird so schnell nicht langweilig.

Ich für meinen Teil kann dieses Spiel absolut empfehlen, vorausgesetzt ihr habt Bock auf einen Haufen Zahlen, Statistiken und Graphen.
Im ersten Moment können diese vielen Knöpfe und Menüs zwar unübersichtlich wirken, aber wenn man einmal dahinter gekommen ist, merkt man schnell, dass alles logisch aufgebaut ist. Außerdem wird alles ausreichend durch Im-Spiel-Tutorials erklärt. Also keine Scheu!^^

Und nur am Rande: die Performance ist für Early Access beispielhaft gut.

26009231.review:
1980 - Have your founder grind through contacts for your first year or two to get some cash in the kitty. Take a few months off to get educated.

1982 - start your first serious development project by hiring a 2-3 staff, a couple to help your founder develop and code, plus a marketer to hit the phones so the thing actually makes money. Rinse, lather and repeat.

1984 - work out that your teams are much happier and more productive if you make one of them a Lead and make the team have meetings and co-ordinate their efforts, and most importantly, get to know each other's most shameful secrets. ("I liked the ewoks!" - *gasp*)

1986 - one of your titles (probably 2D or 3D editor with innovative features) takes off and now you can afford a dedicated team to create an operating system while you have other teams working on smaller projects - mostly sequels to your hit to keep the cash coming.

1990 - Your first OS does well enough to make a reasonable profit, but it's definitely niche and only used by people who've heard of the internet. Start working on Version 2,

1992 - you have enough people working in your firm that you need several cooks to keep them fed. Hope they like spaghetti bolognese.

1995 - Congratulations, you are Microsoft. Commence driving your competitors to the wall until Apple gets Steve Jobs back.

I bought this as EA a while back, it was a bit barebones but the potential was there. Fortunately, development has continued and I am now pleasantly surprised how "sticky" the game is now since I've gotten back into it (October 2016).

There's quite a bit more meat on the bones, and is now pretty compelling as what is basically an office sim - if you work in a office, you can pretty much set up. Software just happens to be the product your worker drones. It is quite dry, but is also cute in its own way. It seems a little more free-form, in that once you get the cashflow working you can set up several teams working on different projects at various stages. (By this point I'd say the UI/UX could use a few quality of life improvements, as you start having to scroll the job list to keep track of it all, but it's really not too bad as is)

I guess if there's one element that could do with some balancing, it's the end-game progression which can hit you pretty quick and the monetary challenge just goes *puff*. But then you can build an enormous office full of drones and commence world domination. The 3D modelling is representative rather than realistic but to me, it's just about right between eye-candy and performance, given that you could potentially employ hundreds (I haven't really pushed the limits yet!).

Of course, this is still in Early Access, so there's probably more features and improvements to come. For instance, maybe more variety of furniture and building objects (although the building system is really quite flexible since you now build things at weird angles), a little more sophistication behind the economic and technology models, although these probably need a tweak more than an overhaul. 

There's also a pretty decent modding scene on Workshop, with a bunch of furniture, building blueprints, as well as new software and even hardware types that you can develop just in case vanilla doesn't give you enough to do.

So def recommend as it is already pretty solid, although I would like to see more stuff added to it.

25734027.review:
Ich Verfolge Software Inc. schon eine weile und konnte mich nicht mehr zurückhalten es mir auch endlich zu zulegen.

[h1]Quick Review![/h1]

Grafik: 7/10
Gameplay: 7/10
Content: 6/10 -->mit Mods 8/10

[h1]Ausführliche Review:[/h1]

[b]Gameplay:[/b]
Software Inc. ist noch in der Early Access Alpha Phase deswegen kann sich im laufe der Zeit die Review ändern, ins Positive oder Negative.
Anfangs erstellt man sich seinen Avatar dem die Firma gehört, und man mekrt das man ziemlich viel Einstellen kann.
Schade finde ich nur das Sachen Wie Haare etc. etwas begrenzt sind und das es noch keine Möglichkeit gibt Mods für das Aussehen zu erstellen.
Hat man sich für sein Aussehen entschieden legt man Fest wie man das Spiel starten will. mit viel oder Wenig Geld oder auf Leicht/ Schwer.
Da es noch keine wirklichen Szenarien von Haus auf gibt kann man sich mit Mods behelfen sofern der Sandbox Modus zu langweilig wird.
Ist man mit allen Einstellungen fertig muss man sich einen Namen für die Firma wählen und startet anschließend mitten ins Spiel.
Eine sache die das Spiel Anfangs grad mit wenig Geld etwas Schwer macht sind die Kosten für Räume denn das kann schnell zum Bankrott führen.
Hat man erstmal die verschachtelten Menüs verstanden fällt es einem Leichter das Spiel und seine Funktionen zu verstehen wie etwa das man geteilte Räume verbinden kann etc. 
Hat man sein Team fertig und hat man einige Aufträge erfüllt und sich ein Polster Angelegt kann man endlich seine eigene Software erstellen, hierbei gefällt mir sehr die grafische Node Fläche wo man klicken kann was man alles für Funktionen in sein Produkt haben will.
Man sollte immer seine Software Vermarkten damit man Fans generiert werden die auch deine Software kaufen.
Nebenbei muss man auf seine Mitarbeiter achten die Bedürnisse haben wie Hunger, stress, denn wenn man nicht aufpasst wollen sie entweder die Firma verlassen oder Verlangen mehr Gehalt dafür das man sie so Missahandelt.
Das Lategame ist noch nicht wirklich Interessant da einige Funktionen noch fehlen da sich das Spiel noch in der Alpha phase befindet.


[b]Grafik:[/b]
Grafik auf jedenfall Gut auch wenn nicht Revolutionär hat aber durchaus seinen Charme.
Viele Grafik Einstellungen zum Experimentieren was für einen passt.


[h1]Ich würde dem Spiel in einer Early Access Katergorie eine 7/10 geben.[/h1] >_

25709902.review:
The first game I played of this kind was Game Dev Tycoon on my mobile phone. This feels somewhat like it, just on a whole different level.

I enjoyed this game a lot yet (and I will enjoy it more!).

Pros:
- Sims-style building with much freedom
- Very funny simulation of workers (e.g. team-meetings and eating in canteen)
- A whole, huge software-ecosystem that you step into with many different software kinds to specialize in
- Intuitive controls, simple and clean UI, everything works beautifully
- I like the graphics-style. No pseudo-realistic shit that drops your performance, just right for a simulation game
- Extensible a lot!

Cons:
- Performance goes to shit after 600 employees for me, even when I set all graphics to very low (Playing with all on high and it gets 60 FPS with lower amounts of employees). There's a lot of space for improvements.
- Only like 10 building stories possible. No trump tower :(
- More software-kinds would be awesome. I also feel that specialization isn't worth it mostly and the impact of education is pretty low. I'd rather have it that one team that developed OS for years shouldn't be able to quickly switch to developing a game. Actively educating employees should feel more rewarding.
- At a later point in the game it seems too easy to simply buy all competitors out,
- Software needs even more traits to choose from, every half year should unlock something new for all software types as at later stages most software you produce is basically the same as before, maybe one new trait added.


Steam Workshop...meh...I'd like to have some kind of object-packs with provide stable new objects to build and maybe new software kinds of many different ways, but I can't really list this as a con, as it's about what the community will produce in the future. I don't want to walk through 4000 pages of steam workshop content (which filters are pretty crappy) just to install a printer-model.

Personally, it was worth every cent and I'm excited about what this game will provide when it's done :)

I love this game. I have several (many!) like it, because I love these kind of management games. This, however, is a cut above the rest already! It's surprisingly deep and seems extremely well balanced for realism; and I do have some experience of this, since I am a software developer for real (yeah, I know... I play a fictional software developer in my free time, now, too!)

Starting off as a struggling developer working out of a 3x2 'shed', reluctantly doing contract work to fund my own pet project, ultimately to be disappointed by the traction of your first and second releases, dealing with exorbitant development licenses just to be able to build your software for the latest and greatest operating systems, and paying for game engines and image editing software and the like. A little later, one of my projects finally catches a few thousand peoples attention, and I make 100k profit from it; enough to increase my office space, add a few creature comforts and take on a likeminded individual to help me with version 2. By the time we complete it, operating systems have moved on, and the money we spent on licenses is all for nought. Fortunately, we are able to port it to the latest version of the OS (at a cost, naturally!).

Fast forward 15 years, and I now employ 40 people including a dedicated design team and support team, and not only do I do my own software, I design, test, support and server host for a range of companies... many that I have bought shares in when they were new in the market, then helped to succeed (or fail... in order to buy a particularly juicy piece of IP from them!.). I have a bunch of team and project leaders to help me delegate and organise; I can't do everything myself! 

I even have my own software distribution system, and now my ambition is to become the next Steam. ;)

As I said, it's a pretty deep game, with research, OS and engine dependancies, porting of software, marketing, trading IPs, stocks and shares etc as well as the people and resource management you expect. Not to mention the freeform building and furnishing of your offices, which gives it an additional and very personal sort of 'The Sims if you were micromanaging their work instead of their lives' vibe, rather than just manipulating a bunch of stats.

Your employees are surprisingly complex, too. They have personality, skills, learning abilities, laziness, likes, dislikes etc that affects their interactions and efficiency as a team. I have employees that I actually hate - that the rest of the team hate - but they're so darn good at their jobs I put up with them. The fact that individual employees can evoke this kind of reaction rather than just being 'some generic employee' is testament to how well this game plays.

So anyway, the fact that you can do all of the above within the confines of a £10 early access game is extremely encouraging and though I'm not sure what else there is to add in an already well rounded game, I'm sure it can only get better. 


tl;dr: I'm always cautious about early access but if you like micromanagement business sims, this is as good as they get and I wouldn't hesitate to recommend it.

25584642.review:
Despite being early access, I already feel like I've gotten my money's worth for this game and given the development roadmap and frequent updates by the developer, I'm confident that this game is just going to get better. I haven't had a game pull me in like this for a while, it's a lot of fun.

The building tools are fantastic, allowing effortless construction, merging of rooms, moving of furniture (with clever grouping of items - ie. move a desk and the chair, computer, phone all move with it). You can build multiple stories and below ground, customise styles and colours, copy and apply styles, it really is one of the nicest building tool-sets I've used, there seems to be a way to do everything from the simple right click menu. The only time I had some trouble with them was when I enclosed an outside area by adding other rooms and couldn't understand why it wasn't behaving like a room should, but once I realised what the problem was I simply used the wall tool to trace the room and could then manipulate it properly.

I really like the variety in the approaches, there appear to be lots of ways to play the game, specialising in different kinds of software, buying and selling IPs, researching new technologies and licensing them, running hosting servers for other companies, as well as a few others. My first software company specialised in making video games (in fact only RPGs and Adventure Games) but I'm really excited to start again and try a completely different approach. It will be interesting to see how many are viable ways to run a successful company.

The tutorial popups are a nice touch, as a lot of early access games throw you in the deep end with little to no guidance of what you should be doing. They're certainly not perfect, and there were definitely times when I was confused about certain aspects and wished there was a little bit more information, but it was definitely helpful when just getting started.

Being early access, there are of course parts of the game that still need to be further fleshed out, there definitely could be more feedback on exactly why certain things fail to sell as well as perhaps adding ways to do market research or see market trends. A lot of the things I felt were missing or incomplete (like software expansions) are already on the development road map for inclusion in future updates so plenty to look forward to.

I wouldn't normally recommend an early access title unless you really wanted to support the developer and help steer development/find bugs, however in this case I think you'll already be getting a fun game on top of that.

24916246.review:
When I play Software Inc. I enjoy the experience, but it feels woefully incomplete, a lack of dificulty from the early game on and pretty much no replay value (I could go and start another save right now, but I know it'd be absolutely boring to do as it'd be copy and paste what I did before, with no real way to take an alternative approach). 

Despite this, I still recommend this game. It's still in Alpha, which means more content should be comming. Hopefully this will make the game more interesting mid-game on and add some replay value to it.

The main reason for recommending the game is it is one of the more unique titles I have seen in a while. You typically get building manangement sims (Prison Architect) or software sims (Game Dev Tycoon). This game blends the two pretty well, along with (rudimentry) stock markets, server farms, being an outsourcing company and adds a touch of controlling whiny, needy things called [strike]sims[/strike] employees.

In essence some one raided EA and stole The Sims and crossed it with software development, and I'm interested to see if they can pull off the game, given the size of the scope.

24911162.review:
Fantastic little gem that delivers beyond expectations. Haven't had this much fun since the original Transport Tycoon.

You're basically a developer / entrepreneur who's come into some money in the 80's / 90's / 2000's (all defined by you before you begin the game) to start a business - in the software industry.

You start off with building a little shed for yourself (similar to your first ever cave in minecraft) and begin coding away. A few contracts for other firms to gather some money and before you know it you're designing your first application. You market it, it sells somewhat decent and you find yourself with a load of cash and start dreaming bigger.

Fast forward to two extra offices and a mid sized team crunching away to deliver what you hope the piece of software that will put you on the map!... But.. things aren't going as fast as you'd hoped and that wad of money you got from your first application is waning dangerously low. In a state of panic you lay everyone off and try and finish the app yourself. It takes forever and you realise you're pretty much broke.

Put the project on hold - grab a few contracts - get yourself some leeway and back to the project! You manage to finish it in twice the time you would find acceptable but there it is anyway. Fingers crossed you do your marketing and release it.

You can't wait for the next day to pluck the fruit of the huge amount of work that went into this - only to find out it sold shit. Mental breakdown, angry muttering and a cigarette break later you decide to be laser sharp this time and bite on what you can chew. You open up the contracts menu - sell every other furnitare in the office and essentially start over again with a tarnished name.

Fast forward again a decade or so and you find yourself thinking if you should upgrade the OS that took the world by storm yet - or focus on cutting edge game engines?

Decisions decisions.

5/5, cool developer, fast updates and a cheap game that is worth it's money at it's current state two times over. And this is all in ALPHA... not even BETA!

Must buy :)

The good: Nice graphics, great attention to detail, it has a special type of charm, something between Sim City and being realistic. A lot of interesting details like room temperature. Good UI, you can clone entire rooms if you want.

The bad: Well, I really want to like this game but I can't. I can't find any real pattern within in. Sometimes you create something and you earn $5.000.000. Other times you don't. No feedback on what works or not whatsoever. The game is complex but this is not the problem. The problem is that 90% of the time, there are formulas you have no idea about working behind it.

For example, you can get the IP to a software that will earn you millions for a few tens of thousands. On the other hand, you need to pay millions for a software that generates virtually nothing. As a matter of fact, if you simply want to skip playing the game, just get some money through projects and buy IPs. The first time I've done this, I've made close to a billion in a single day. 

Plus, I don't understand how it scales. I can get 100 programmers, 100 designers and 100 artists and put them to work on a single project but honestly, it will be just as fast as using five of them. Great presentation, great concept but the mechanics feel broken on a level I can't explain. I'll just stick to something else.

24615859.review:
This game is basically if Game Dev Tycoon had a child that became the Renaissance Man it father couldn't become in owning a company that doesn't have to just focus on gaming itself. You could be the owner of a huge business with many micro teams while a main team owns and runs the entire company. With a huge engrossing on the power of time technology has grown in, making better upgrades to your company and having a better array of decoration, power, and servers for your company to have. It makes the game seem endless in design, and in ways, it is if you added custom scenarios or just go on the "Free-play" mode.
Even though the game is still in alpha, it still has it's gritty bugs that can be annoying, but, the developer is quick in their bug fixes. Having at least weekly to bi-weekly updates to the game. Even allows users to go to the unstable build of the game if they so desire to; to see how the progess is going in the game, frankly myself goes on the unstable build but however it's very stable, just some bugs like a simple menu not popping up or already minimized. But with the game still being in alpha, it's offered me over 25 hours of enjoyment. And I still have that itch to keep playing the game but personally I want to wait until the next build before I go and play the game. 
"The game is overly complicated," or "This or this doesn't work, negative review cause so and so," are obvious oversensitive remarks about the game to just give it a negative review, making buyers fear that the game is way too difficult. Honestly it's not, it's just a game of trial and error. You're working in the techno world of business, you have your ups and downs, and the game gives you a loan of 50k USD to help get you on your feet and yes, you have to pay back the loan with interests. It's a business game, not a simple, "Oh you failed, have some candy," kind of game. It still has that sense of realism to it. But once you get to make your perfect game/web site/program/etc., you're basically rolling in dough, then you can build your office from there. From a small studio team to a huge, multi-tree, organization. 

I personally give this game a great recommendation for the progress it has, how often the developer continues to update their game, and how much fun I'm personally having looking at people slam their hands on their keyboards. It makes me want to say, "Damn, if only working on PC's were that easy."

Unbalanced far past the point of being absolutely ridiculous.

It took me maybe 4 tries to get a company to survive more than a year. Even bumping the starting cash from $10,000 to $50,000 it was impossible to get anywhere before ultimately going bankrupt. Eventually I hit upon a winning strategy, with a founder skilled at programming and another employee for design, cranking out constant contracts ($30,000 worth a month) and putting a few hours every day into a game. This was a really un-fun amount of micromanagement, having to click 50 different prompts to advance the contracts through the different stages of completion before the month whizzed by and I was bankrupt again. Eventually after like two years enough work had been done on the game to release it to 300,000 people, where it got maybe 3,000 sales and I was back to constant near-bankruptcy. I hired two cheap marketers and started on the same plan with more or less the exact same details, a programmer and a designer spending their spare time when not doing contract work working on the game. This time, with 2 marketers working non-stop before and after release, It made $8 million in a few months and at that point there was no real reason to keep playing.

This game is a chore until it isn't, at which point there's nothing left to do.

So, I'll go ahead and get this out of the way. Yes, I have played over 275 hours in this game, and yes, my review is still a thumbs down, but only by a slim margin.

My first review was incredibly brief, and positive. I liked the customization, loved the mechanics, and all together found the game a GREAT time waster. However, as this is an early access game, it has shifted in direction and evolved as updates have been released. Some of these changes are really great, but in its current state, I cannot recommend this game. The balance went from forgiving and inviting, to a perfect glass ceiling, in which you will not, no matter how well you play, reach in the billions of dollars as you could in previous titles. Sometimes, it takes me 10-15 in game years to reach $50mil, other times, longer. This frustrating brick wall, combined with new distribution systems, Sound - which is difficult to work around, resulting in several office rebuilds, and other new implimentations, make me think twice about recommending it.

There is a good game in here, I've seen it firsthand, but it's not where it needs to be. If/when the game changes, I'll be back to change the review! 24501860.review:
I've been playing this game since I think around Alpha 1.4, and the progress has been consistently top notch. The continutation of adding depth and the subsequent variation that provides is resulting in one of the best management simulations I have played in recent years. Add to that the fact that this is a one-man operation makes it all the more impressive. 

I'm not generally a fan of the graphical style used here. However, that this is all done by one person makes it a sensible and pragmatic design choice, and I think it works very well. 

I'd like to see some more options in the way of keeping track of employees, as I find that once I get beyond a staff of 10, I'm more focussed on building an overall cohesive unit, as opposed to perhaps focusing on the individuals within the team. I'd also like to be able to see what role a retired employee used to do, and perhaps have the option to increase their pension! I do feel bad when someone retires early on, and they're essentially left with a pittance compared to employees who retire later. 

The development mechanics work very well, with the addition of overstaffed teams having a negative impact on the development of a given product. I love being able to create and expand my company office space, and I think the tools given to do that are very well implemented. I'd like to have more choice in terms of items and equipment, maybe with different brands, each with their own advantages and disadvantages, and perhaps even with employees preferring a certain brand. For example, in terms of office equipment, Dell vs HP vs Viglen vs Apple. 

I would love to see implemented a mechanic where if you buy out a company, you can keep it operating, perhaps elevating one of your team leaders to oversee that company, and build a larger conglomerate within the game world.

I haven't yet checked out the latest Alpha, but I am excited to see where the developer goes with the game, and I really thoroughly recommend it to anyone who loves an immersive management sim. Kudos to the developer, you've made a cracker of a game! :)

24381794.review:
I normally don't go for Early Access Games but this one really caught my attention and the price couldn't be beat. 

Ultimately, this still clearly a game in alpha. A lot of the features still need developing but it plays as a solid, if sometimes bare-bones Tycoon game. That being, said, it is one of the most complex Simulation games I've ever experienced. You have a great deal of customization with the software you put out, and micromanaging your team is surprisingly enjoyable. 

One of my favorite parts, however, is office customization. Using a Sims-style building system, you construct an office to meet the needs of your staff and your development style. It's surprising how rigorous this system is even with the admittedly little content the game currently has. I daresay 40% of my playtime is customizing and recustomizing my office as I grow and adjust my company. 

There are some things that definitely still need work. The sheer amount of information to keep track of is often overwhelming, but very little of it seems relevant. I imagine a little simplification is in order paired with some better UI design. Furthermore, sometimes building or managing individual staff members can get frustrating due to the counterintuitive order of actions you have to do to move an object or assign a computer to someone. 

Overall, an absolutely excellent experience even in this alpha phase, even if it definitely needs some improvements before it can be the excellent Tycoon game it is so clearly shaping up to be.

-PROS-
-Complexity for days, interlocking systems and plenty of control of every minor decision.
-Extreme Customization, moreso than I've seen in almost any other Tycoon game.
-Simple, low-poly visual style lends itself well without looking cheesy.
-Very flexible difficulties and decent tutorials to learn at your own pace
-Excellent mod support, with plenty of Custom Content in the workshop.

-CONS-
-Missing music and sound. VERY lacking from an Audio standpoint. Dev says he has contracted out for music, so hopefully that will be in here soon.
-Clunky, Ugly UI.  Arguably my biggest complaint. While certain parts move sleekly, the UI is very poorly designed, flow from one window to another is confusing and the presentation of information makes it unclear what you're supposed to be prioritizing. The general aesthetic of the UI also leaves much to be desired.
-The Simulation and Competition doesn't really feel present in the current build. The news feature I never check aside from when I release software and there's no announcements of developments or new technology, so it's hard to get a feel for how you should be driving your company in light of the competition.
-The lack of content is apparent, and hopefully will be continued to be rectified. This is a game that thrives from it's rich, deep simulation, so the few items that come in game are frustratingly limiting.

24304731.review:
As a fan of tycoon and resource management games, this immediately caught my attention and I sat and watched - the asthetic factor of the game and the sheer amount of things to do in it perked my ears right up. The first time I dove in, I went in with baited breath and expected to absorb just about everything it had in store for me within a few hours. I was dead wrong about that.

In fact, it almost bombarded me with micromanagement details, from the smallest character flaws of potential employees to a robust server system and a catalog of options on types of software to zone in on and carve my very own virtual niche in the market. It was everything I wanted, and much more. Almost too much more. An overwhelming sense of more.

It was a bit much, more than I expected, and I admit to not catching onto the learning curve until my second jump in.

Once I caught it, however, it's been non-stop. 

So there is a bit of a learning curve to it, but the tutorials are nice and simple and helpful. For once, I caught myself wanting those tutorials, rather than letting my hand go to roam about on my own.

What an enjoyable game. The freedom and flexibility to either stay super small, a clique of "buds" that just crank out some indy games and scrape by, riding the waves of the popular tides and not making waves. Or a multi-billion dollar company churning out market-smashing operating systems and taking the world by storm - along with literally everything, and I mean everything, in between.

Can't stop. Don't wanna stop. Just want to keep on keepin' on. I want to do a game with this idea, or that principal, or start a new company to try a different venue all before even getting my hands dirty in my current one. 

Love it. Absolutely love it.

- You can make hundreds of decisions. You can develop an OS, an Audio Tool or even a game (and a lot more) and you can go into specifics for each piece of software. What OS should your game run on, what engine does it use, what features do you want to have,... You have hundreds of options to create exactly what you want!
- You can hire hundreds of workers and divide them into teams. You can have a support team who support your already released software, you can have a Sports Game team who releases a new Fifa every year,... SO MANY POSSIBILITIES!
- You can build your company's HQ like a sims game. Build rooms, add windows, buy servers, pcs, drawing tablets, plants, build parking spots, elevators, a reception desk, air conditioning,...
- Your workers have needs and you need to fulfill them. They don't want to work in a cold and loud room with a bunch of people who don't fit their personality!
- You can automate a lot of work. If you want you can do most stuff by yourself but after 20+ employees it becomes tedious to look for new meat and you might want to hire a team leader who helps you with that. Same goes for cleaning, maintenance, IT support,...
- You have competition out there. Be it other games, a console, 3D software tools or even a store (yes, you can create your own version of Steam and dominate the PC platform) - you have competition. You can look up all (upcoming) releases in a database, look at their features, success,...
- There is soooo much more, too much to cover (Insurance, Stocks, Advertising, server management,...)
- The graphics are cute and it runs very well (not sure how good it runs once you have 1000+ employees but so far it runs stable on highest settings without a single crash)
- Steam workshop support
- The industry changes fast. You can't just release your software on the same OS with the same tools for 20 years. You have to take risks. For example I created the first game engine with 3D rendering but at the time there was only one OS with 3D rendering support which had only sold ~100k units. I took the gamble and still developed the engine for that OS and thankfully their operating system took off so my engine did as well. What if their OS didn't get popular? I would have had a huge problem! Great risk/reward!

Bad:
- The interface can sometimes be a bit clunky
- Generic names for competitors so you forget them too quickly (Did I release my game on OS7 or OS8? Or was it Pen7 or Pen8?). Maybe colors/logos would help, I don't know.

Verdict:
I am totally in love with this game. And it isn't even close to being finished yet. The first hour can be a bit slow (thankfully the tutorial is solid) but then the game takes off. Expanding your company, taking risks, eating competitors and being part of history is very rewarding and fun. At that price point this game is a steal!

Probably the best tycoon game I have played in a long time. I sat on the fence about buying this game for a long time because the trailer and the screenshots made me a little cautious. After reading some reviews I decided to try it... boy am I glad I did.

The tutorials are excellent. The mechanics and design are fantastic. It is a very complex game but it's surprisingly intuitive. It's not an "easy" game to pick up, but it is also not an overly confusing game. There are some extremely unique design aspects that marry up the more casual approach to tycoon games, with the complexity of building we see in titles like "the sims". This is something I have not seen before and this game successfully melds the casual tycoon and construction genres.

The art style is a perfect blend of simplicity and substance. It suits the title perfectly and looks amazing. Performance is excellent. I am operating on the beta branch and have encountered no bugs.

If you, like I was, am sitting on the fence - I would strongly recommend you buy this game. It's in an excellent state.

23866658.review:
If you ever wondered what it'd be like to run your own tech startup, then you owe it to yourself to get this game. Do not get this game if you aren't comfortable with failing and learning.

I was a bit hesitant to purchase Software Inc. because of the early acccess bit, but after browsing the game's official forums and the steam forums I can see that the developer pays attention to and shares information with the community. For being a solo developer, that's quite impressive and I'm glad that I can support him by getting his game.

Regarding the actual gameplay, it's essentially Game Dev Tycoon on steroids with the Sims, with micromanagement and far more complex mechanics. You will fail multiple times on your first few companies until you learn how to get off the ground and stay above the red. I enjoyed the learning process because I felt it somewhat emulated real life tech startups (failing multiple times to succeed).

Once you grasp the core mechanics and gameplay loop, you'll find quite a few interesting systems to interact with. Some of these systems are as follows:

1) A stock market (you can release stocks, buy out other companies, etc.)
2) Distribution networks (change who sells your software, online/brick-n-mortar, etc.)
3) Server management (some software will require you to set up a network for server access)
4) Employees/teams (build teams, assign work to them, train/management)
5) Research
6) Development cycle (design, alpha, marketing, beta, post-release support)
7) Mods (easy to mod due to developer support, almost anyone can mod XML files)

So yeah. Get the game if you're on the fence about it. It's a fantastic simulation game even in alpha with great promise and a developer who communicates with his community.

Criei a DICE, lancei a Frostbite, e depois todos os Battlefields em cima da mesma engine.

Fui a falência quando lancei o Battlefield 1, com os piores reviews.

Hora de criar a Actvision...

-- 
Editei a analise para poder falar um pouco melhor sobre esse jogo.

Olha, Software Inc. é um jogo ótimo, e perfeito para quem curte um gerenciamento e simulação, inclusive para quem é desenvolvedor(a) (como eu) e que adora os meandros desta área. Já me diverti muito criando empresas mega bilionárias que praticamente dominam o mercado, como também ja criei empresas mais enxutas que fizeram bilhões apenas com poucos produtos. 

Com a ajuda de alguns mods é possível deixar o jogo melhor, mais opções de softwares a serem desenvolvidos, possibilidade de se começar nos anos 70 por exemplo e começar com um dinheiro absurdamente reduzido. Como os arquivos são em XML, eu mesmo editei alguns deles para deixar o jogo mais dificil, como os softwares que dependem de auto-update, se tiverem muita venda, consumirem muito de um servidor, obrigando a você criar verdadeiras "server farm" gigantescas com teras e mais teras e mais teras de capacidade.

Maaas agora vamos aos problemas.

O jogo é facil, bem fácil, não há muita dificuldade nele, apenas algumas decisões erradas no começo podem te fazer ir a falência, mas... é 90% de chances de você "vender bem" no primeiro produto, e dai, você só vai crescer, crescer e crescer e virar arqui-bilionário com dinheiro suficiente para comprar o Planeta Terra.

O Desenvolvedor planeja inserir algumas coisas como uma nova distribuição (ao invés de digital) como física também, porque não é realista nos anos 80/70 existir distribuição por via de download. Ele também fará um "rework" no desenvolvimento do produto, substituindo a barra de progresso por linhas de código, o que vai ficar muito melhor, já que um produto não precisa ser "outstanding" para ser lançado. 

O Desenvolvedor também planeja criar subsidiárias (através de empresas compradas por você, te permitindo gerenciá-las), conferências (como E3 por exemplo) e você ter que planejar e bancar tudo isso. Code Leak do teu projeto, Hackearem o seu produto, distribuição pirata, dentre outras.

Tudo isso é muito legal mesmo, porém, eu citei o "desenvolvedor" ali em cima, no singular, e é isso mesmo que você entendeu, o jogo é desenvolvido por apenas um único cara. Nada contra isso, eu também desenvolvo jogos e no solo mode, e sei a dificuldade que é isso... Assim como sei que, muitas dessas coisas que ele pretende fazer, vão demorar bastante tempo ainda para serem implementadas.

O jogo avança de forma bem lenta infelizmente, e eu não vejo ele saindo do alpha (que a steam chama de "acesso antecipado" para soar mais bonito) nem tão cedo. É dificil afirmar que o desenvolvedor deveria chamar uma equipe para trabalhar com ele, pois apenas ele sabe o quanto ele lucrou com o jogo na steam, e se ele não chamou, é porque provavelmente não foi o suficiente para manter uma equipe trabalhando por todo esse tempo.

Eu o apoio, visito o seu fórum, inclusive ele mantém um trello ativo onde você pode acompanhar o andamento do projeto, e também, onde ele faz alguns brainstorms sobre futuras idéias.

Eu recomendo este jogo, para você que gosta de simulação e gerenciamento e também desenvolve, seja pra web, app, software, você vai adorar certamente.

Aproveita, e da uma força ao desenvolvedor, visitando o seu trello e o fórum!

Software Inc. 顾名思义就是软件公司。开公司，卖软件，赚大钱，走上人生巅峰，迎娶白富美，一套一套的。

虽然游戏还是EA状态，但是我觉得核心功能跟大部分界面已经很完善了。
给喜欢模拟经营类游戏的朋友们推荐一波，顺便感受一下苦逼程序员和设计师的日常。

基本流程就是，先做外包，等攒了一点钱，就开发自己的产品，慢慢成长。然后开辟新的市场，靠着海量的粉丝和市场宣传，基本上入一行霸一行，是不是感觉自己变成了马化腾。。。

跟<游戏开发模拟>的区别，除了可以开发更多种类的软件之外，对员工的管理更细致，加入了市场和渠道的操作，另外作为补充，可以不做软件而是做云服务，或者做设计/开发/支持/市场的外包服务。

这游戏的开发迭代蛮快的，想玩新功能的可以加入测试。（不像某游戏虽然迭代快，但是都推送到正式版，结果一堆BUG）

不玩mod和建筑的话，游戏时间在20小时左右，再多就是刷数据了。
鉴于已经比较完善了，推荐入，无需等正式发行。

23639294.review: Not a review. Just a thumbs up to a pretty fun, considered and addictive management game.

23637613.review:
I had about £3 in my Steam Wallet, and a few more £'s in my bank account. I was bored so I started browsing the store looking and hoping to stumble into a gem of a game.

Normally that doesn't happen, normally I stumble into another early access money-grab. But not this time, not at all.

I've been constantly surprised with the depth of this game, and what it has to offer. It's a fantastic simulation that will reward you greatly for paying attention to the information that it provides you regarding other companies and what people are using, software wise.

There's no dispute that the simulation is at the forefront in the game 90% of the time, but the workplace building is extremely easy, and intuitive to use. You can make some really nice stuff - especially if you check out the workshop beforehand for some of the mods that add additional decoration props.

The game tells you to build a place for your start-up company, and recommends taking some contract work to get a bit of quick money. This teaches you the ropes of how to manage your employees while they're working. Then it'll ask you to start hiring some staff, and to do this you have to pay for and manage an interview process, which allows you to choose a good fit for your company. Then it'll ask you to build some software, and oh boy, does the game open up here. You have to consider a bunch of things, like what competition will be releasing soon, how long it will take you to finish the software, how big your audience will be which is defined by what operating systems you choose to build the software for.. and I could go on. It's so in depth and if you love that kind of thing then this game is definitely for you.

Make sure you follow the tutorials at least once, as they'll teach you some vital stuff, it's so worth it when you get that first overnight million in the bank and it feels like you earned it because you were managing everything to earn it.

Another thing to note is the dev seems really active with the community, and is also building the game out with more features at quite a fast pace, which is fantastic and refreshing to see in the early access scene.

The game is quite solid. I haven't encountered any bugs so far (not even on the test builds), everything seems to be fairly balanced and the simple graphics work really well. It's always exciting when starting up a new game, but quickly there comes a point where it starts being dull and boring.

All of the softwares start feeling the same and the only thing which I can do with all of the money is to build a bigger office, hire more employees, and make more softwares to continue the cycle, none of which are very variational. It's very easy to make a multi-million game, and it is impossible to have any chance of losing once you create one. Difficulties seem to only affect the needs of employees, so those don't change a lot either.

There is mod support, but the most interesting mods are furniture mods. The rest are just a bunch of software compilations which, as previously mentioned, are nearly indistinguishable from one another apart from different markets and creation times.

But maybe it's just the genre that I don't enjoy.

23295051.review:
Software Inc. has to be the of the most underrated games on Steam. I accidentally found it while searching for tycoon games and what a surprise it was! This is the best software development game I've played compared with Game Dev Tycoon, GamersGoMakers, Mad Games Tycoon etc.

What sets it apart is the simple graphics and the smooth interface. It is easy to learn the controls and build big impressive looking office complexes. 

You start as the founder of the company starting to work on a few small contracts. From there you start developing your own software: Antivirus, games, operating systems, audio and visual design software, ect. As you grow, you can expand your office and workforce. It's entirely up to you how much you'd like to micromanage. You can assign team leaders and send them on HR and project management courses allowing them to hire and manage teams and their own projects completely independently. The game scales incredibly well as you expand your company.

Some might find the micromanagement a little overwhelming. This game was really well thought out and you have all the data you might need at your disposal.

It is early access so there are some glitches, and the game could do with more content. Most notably furniture is currently a bit limited, but that said all the necessary stuff is already there. There's also some minor balancing issues that will be sorted out later but nothing gamebreaking and nothing that will ruin your fun. So far the developer of Software Inc. has built a great foundation for what will probably become one of the most unique and fun management simulations on the market.

In the simulation/management genre, this game is right up there with the best of them.

[b]THE GOOD[/b]
- Great interface
- Level of micromanagement is optional
- Regular updates
- Workshop support

[b]THE BAD[/b]
- Still Early Access
- Limited content
- Ballance issues

[h1]9/10[/h1]

DISASTER | BAD | MEDIOCRE | OKAY | GOOD | GREAT | [b][u]AMAZING[/u][/b] | MASTERPIECE

23131852.review:
I played this game the whole of yesterday and it is really addictive. I love the concept and it is implemented quite well except there are many things that need to be improved.

Pros:
+ Really fun to play (one of those games where you look up and realise you've lost half the day.. and night)
+ Graphics aren't mindblowing but are fit for purpose
+ A lot more options and content then Game dev Tycoon

Cons:
- Gui needs serios work, why can't I shift camera angles with the mouse, everything is on the keyboard
- Some important info menus are missing, I can't find anything that shows a breakdown of my sales for the month
- Building mechanics are a little backwards and need improvement. Parking lots are laid down opposite to their icon for instance. You also cannot delete walls and you need enclose a whole square on existing walls before walls are set. Why can't I just lay a single section of walls, to create a passage way between two rooms for instance.
- Need more furniture and upgrades. There is too much of a gap between 1990 and 2000
- The interface for assigning teams to projects needs to be in a single screen, where you can drag and drop and see where they allocated/overallocated
- What about creating toilet cubicles.... why must I enclose each toilet with a wall?
- I don't understand/like the HR manager and Project Manager implementation, why aren't these separate roles like IRL
- I know the same is about Software, but why not introduce a Hardware manufacturing element (DLC maybe?). Would be fund to be an Apple/Microsoft and Manufacture the hardware to go with my Phone software/Console etc.
- Pricing: There should be a metric indicating public price sensitivity. Otherwise it's a guessing game. Perhaps you can commission a report to see what people think about your product and suggested pricing points?
- Time to develop should increase with better equipment, it doesn't feel like this every changes
- Servers never seem to keep up with demand and the wiring mechanic is screwed. Why can't they all be linked together, there seems to be some arbitrary limitation that is beyond comprehension?!!?
- Stocks: There has to be a better way to implement this. Also it would be cool to be able to take control of companies after you own more than 50% and set their objectives. i.e. what they can and can't make. I'd also like to be able to set their dividens level, some like in capitalism.

Don't let the many con's above put you off this game, it is really cool and well worth the money, it just needs a good few tweaks to make it awesome.

22933585.review:
De prime abord, à la lecture de la description du jeu, j'ai été moyennement tenté, d'autant que les graphismes ne semblaient pas extraordinaires (certes, pour un jeu de gestion, ce n'est pas le plus important). Après avoir vu un let's play en français (Bill Silverlight), suivi d'un let's play en anglais, j'ai absolument voulu l'acheter. L'aspect gestion est très bien développé, le design finalement tout à fait adapté et agréable, et l'aspect building (construction des locaux de votre studio de développement) est suffisamment complet (sans être Les Sims non plus) pour m'avoir intéressé. le jeu possède une bonne rejouabilité : on peut décider en début de partie de ne développer que des jeux vidéo, ou bien que des OS, ou au contraire de tout ; on peut décider de se spécialiser sur la plateforme PC, ou la plateforme console ; on peut enfin s'amuser à imaginer différents types de bâtiments complémentaires, ou bien un seul grand bâtiment. Et le jeu propose de commencer son entreprise à la décennie que l'on souhaite.

Je conseille très vivement ce jeu : une fois une partie commencée, dur, très dur, d'arrêter.

Un point négatif : les FPS sont en chute libre, avec toutes options graphiques au minimum (et un PC de gamer respectable), au-dessus de 500 salariés, rendant le jeu très pénible à jouer ; c'est extrêmement frustrant d'être pénalisé techniquement lorsque l'on a réussi à faire prospérer son entreprise. Mais le jeu sera probablement optimisé au fil de la bêta.
Point d'amélioration : ajouter un peu plus de choix de mobilier pour l'aspect construction, tant dans la déco que dans les PC (différents PC, pour chaque époque, avec différentes caractéristiques ?).
