16608114.review:
[url=http://uberswe.com/software-inc-review-and-gameplay-alpha-4-7/]Blog Post[/url] | [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t_bxezwyCuM]YouTube Video[/url]

The first time I saw this game I almost fell out of my seat. Finally a game that could compete with another one of my favorites, Game Dev Tycoon. This game resembles Game Dev Tycoon but takes everything a step further basically.

So what is Software Inc. about? In this game you start and run your own software company where you will need to manage a budget, your team and make decisions on what to create and how to market it among other things. You can also build your own office and buy more land. Different teams can be assigned to different rooms and work on different projects while another team does something else. You can also hire maintenance crews to come clean, do maintenace or provide IT support for your released products.

In this game you can create games as we have seen in other similar games but here you can also make operating systems, visual tools, audio tools and game engines which can all be used to make other software. You can also chose to keep your software in-house, release and sell it or open source it and give it away for free.

Oh and did I say you can have multiple floors for your office? and you can build parking lots? There is so much you can do in this game that I won’t be able to fit all the good parts in this review.

So what are the negatives? Well the graphics could be improved but I rather have good gameplay than graphics and I did not feel that it took away from the fun of the game. There were also some small bugs where I couldn’t rotate a set of objects when moving them but these are to be expected in an early access game.

In future updates I would love to see more items, better stock value (it should be more advanced than just following the cash in the company), and possibly multiplayer if it can be done in a nice way.

I would recommend buying this game, it is already great fun and the developer seems active with regular updates. I hope that this will continue but as you know with any early access game, you never know what the final outcome will be like.

16367427.review:
If you liked Game Dev Story and its clones, you will love this.

This game is a one man effort, so the graphics are quite simple (but they are clean and they do the job). 
What's really impressive about Software Inc. is its depth and complexity. It's a real simulation where you can build and control everything. Its scope is huge as well. Not only can you develop your own games, but also other kind of software and operating systems, and reuse them for bigger projects.

You need to handle your employees' satisfaction, behavior, compatibility with each other, salary expectations and regular raises, skill training, and so on. You build and maintain every piece of your office, and you need to keep it functional, accounting for light, noise, cleanliness and temperature levels. As your office and employee pool grow, you create different teams that can work on multiple projects at the same time. You can even build a multi-story building!

All the aspects of software development seem to be present and well implemented, despite the early access state of the game: contract work, design / alpha / beta phases, debugging, marketing, distribution channels, support (fixing bugs reported by customers), team leadership, market shares, server management, competitors... Heck, you even hire cleaners and IT support to maintain your office.

Despite its depth, it's easy to learn, thanks to the tutorials that appear automatically each time you try something new. I'm usually not into management games and I don't like micro-management, but here nothing seemed tedious, and so far my game sessions have been very enjoyable. I'm waiting to see how it scales up with many employees and a big office.

Since it's in early access, there's no music (yet) and not many sound effects. Just use your usual music player and you will be good to go. Apart from that, it feels like a polished game already and I didn't encounter any bugs.

This is a little gem that can only get better.

16180085.review:
10 hours of gaming later, and here's my inital thoughts on Software Inc.

Pros:
+ Addictive
+ Art Scheme
+ Endless Amounts of Opportunity and Fun. You can start off in the 80's and become a company like Microsoft, or start off in the modern era and struggle to compete with the major names in the market. The possibilities are very large, and each playthrough brings different cards to the table with randomly generated stuff and things.
+ Dynamic Stock Market
+ Reputation System, has a few kinks here and there, but still, its there.

Cons:
- Glitchy, Clippy, 90's-esque Graphics. If you NEED amazing graphics, this Alpha is not for you.
- Slightly unbalanced difficulty settings.
- No music? Minor, but definitely something I enjoy having in a game that takes HOURS at a time to play (D:)
- Super. F***ing. Needy. Employees. No. Really. Expect to deal with, "I NEED TO PEE, THE BATHROOM IS RIGHT OVER THERE, BUT INSTEAD OF GOING TO THE BATHROOM, IM GOING TO ASK FOR A RAISE." a lot. Cheap, dirty bastards.
- Overall, a lot of improvements/fixes/adjustments to be made (that's why it's an Alpha :D)

If you're into strategies and want to get behind something new, innovative, and extremely addicting, then you've come to the right place. Although there are still PLENTY of bugs at this stage, the developer seems rather set on game development, even if his abilities are limited. Take those twelve bucks you were going to spend on Junk Food to support a great game. :D

16165695.review:
Software Inc. is a The Sims less then but more eager to be more cousin. When I say that I mean imagine a game where your Sims can have a custom job and live in a custom made office with your own staff and everything. So far I was able to sample the game enough to get a fair and accurate review of Software Inc. and I have to say... its different.

I made a boss named the Canadian Devil and the business Pay2Win Inc. I first didn't understand how the staffing worked but I played a few game developer clones and quickly found my way around although I had to restart a couple times. My first mistake was making 2 rooms one with a kitchen and one the main office but found out that you can only have one team per room and so I stuck my advertising team in the kitchen with the bathrooms, the team would call in sick then quit after two months reporting to news that well I was the Canadian Devil not letting them pee and eat. Then I realized every project I started took six to eight months to just get the bare minimum and have the reviews say "surprise Pay2Win made yet another bad product." and only sell 50 units. I finally found out that you can take on jobs for other businesses to earn some quick and more effective cash however sending staff to school seemed like more of sending them to Las Vegas for a week.

Overall the game delivered what it said it was but there's 1 glaring issue that should be addressed minus the 4x timer sometimes makes the time go faster and the workers stay at 2x but the lack of a good tutorial to show players what does what and why. Don't get me wrong I still recommend this game but I recommend it as a fun "The Sims at work" type game for now. I'll keep this review updated.

16125975.review:
There are many new software/game tycoon games available, but none of them reach this level of detail. As the sole developer of this game, the developer has put a lot of time into this game and actively logs updates (seen here at [url=https://trello.com/b/9I286Mhu/software-inc]his Trello page[/url]. The workflow is clearly labelled and categorized, and you can easily know what he plans to do with the games. The developer is also active on the [url=http://www.swinc.net/forum/]forums[/url], both Steam and his own.

While in the game, you can:
[list]
[*]Build a huge company on a huge chunk of property (256x256 grid!)
[*]Manage multiple teams at once. (One could be dedicated to Marketing, or you could just automate the whole process!)
[*]Buy/sell stocks to gain money and rights. (WARNING: There are plans to overhaul the whole system)
[*]Buyout your competition and laugh while you gain their profits
[*]Develop over 5 kinds of software (There are plans to add more)
[*]Link up multiple servers and run your own distribution network or host your source code
[*]Hire/fire staff and employees to help maintain your company
[*]Go bankrupt and have to sell out 75% of your company's stocks for profit.
[*]Educate team members to increase their effectiveness and make more profits
[*]And last but not least, this game had mod support! While the community is relatively small, there is enough mod documentation on the wiki to make your own if needed! 
[/list]

In short, get this game NOW because he has plans to increase the cost near release. It is in a playable state as is, and you can easily get around the bugs. In my opinion, this game has a lot of potential and is well-worth the money as is.

15924466.review:
Это игра про создание, развитие и управление софтверной фирмой. Игра чем-то напоминает GameDev Tycoon с тем отличием, что GameDev Tycoon - это игра про разработчиков игр, а Software Inc - это игра про софтверную компанию в общем виде (и игры в том числе). Ну и как следствие, она отличается бОльшим разнообразием и широтой, чем GameDev Tycoon. Графика весьма условная, но в играх такого жанра она стоит далеко не на первом месте. Ключевые особенности:
- можно нанимать программистов, дизайнеров, художников, пиарщиков
- возможность построить здание компании с нуля, оснастить комнаты мебелью и оборудованием. В этом плане она очень напоминает старую игрушку Theme Hospital
- возможность работы как по контрактам с заказчиками, так и создание своего собственного софта: операционных систем, видео и аудио программ, игровых движков, самих игр, антивирусов. Список возможно неполный, т.к категории софта открываются не сразу все, я лишь привел то, до чего добрался сам, играя вчера вечером.
- можно создавать софт как проприетарный, так и опенсорсный. Во втором случае деньги на нем заработать нельзя, но это здорово прибавляет популярности фирме.
- возможность организовывать свои собственные серверные!
- фондовая биржа: можно продавать как акции своей компании, так и скупать акции других компаний. Туториал говорит, что можно даже поглощать компании, скупая более 50% акций, хотя я сам не пробовал это делать.
Игра находится в раннем доступе. И хотя я в последнее время отношусь с предубеждением к играм с таким статусом, в случае данной игры я даже рад этому. Потому что это значит, что то немалое, что в ней уже есть, будет дополняться со временем новыми функциями. Linux-версия работает отлично, никаких нареканий и багов. Язык игры - английский, русского нет. Нормальный ITшный английский язык, понятный большинству. Я не думаю, что будут какие-то трудности. В начале игры и на каждое меню есть туториал, в котором прекрасно объясняются все функции.
Любителям экономических тайкунов игру очень рекомендую, мне она очень понравилась.

15909366.review:
With only 4 hours in I feel like i have barely grasped the game in depth. It took me a few tries to figure out the mechanics and to have a game where I didn't go bankrupt.  Here is a small pro/con breakdown:

pros;
-Feels like a class tycoon game, start from the bottom and work to the top
-Has a plethora of in game tasks to keep the player busy, from managing teams to seeking out contracts to complete all the way to building up your offices to expand for more employees.
-On the other spectrum, it also has a "Sims" feel meaning you can literally build new rooms/buildings for more space, place equipment & furniture, each having direct impact on your firm.
-The interface is aesthetically pleasing to the eyes and is easy to interpret. 
-Spreadsheets & numbers for the statistic-savy folks. 
-In game stock market including loans you can withdraw for more cash on hand to do whatever with.
-And by the looks of it many many other features i haven't yet experienced.

Cons;
-Albeit the game is in alpha, there is still glaring room for improvement. 
-Graphics/Audio are by no means on a AAA standard, so if you are wanting some crazy high-resolution ultra HDR direct x90000 quality graphics, move along. (This isn't really a con for me, i don't care about graphics or audio for these types of games).
-Some finicky in game mechanics could use some fleshing out such as how effectiveness & happiness numbers really work. 
-A few graphical glitches but do not have an impact on gameplay.

One last line,

This game has so much potential, a fellow Dane appears to be the primary (or only?) developer for this title, and so far he/she is off to a great start. I will continue playing, and will follow development closely.

15818897.review:
Pretty basic at its current state. Graphics are plain, but I don't normally care about graphics in the first place so it doesn't bother me. It is quite funny to see the animation of your employees, it is like they are just hitting their keyboard very hard.

The game is unique for its type. It is a lot better than Dev Tycoon or other related games by far. There's more to do and you aren't limited on what you can do. Expand, hire employees, manage, make servers, connect servers, make Software for your company and many more features. There's a ton of management in this game too, which is great.

Tutorials are buggy and a few systems could use some touching up. It has its bugs, but what Early Access game doesn't?

The main problem I came across was, is the game is too easy. Given 1 hour of my played time was reading through the tutorials and learning how the game works. However, once you get your skills up (Marketing mainly: which doesn't take long) for your employees, money is too easy to receive. Of course that means you can expand further and try to dominate your competitors. I created an OS with just two employees (recommended was 7 team members) and I received over $950,000 in revenue, after that I still gained over hundreds of thousands every month until it finally stopped. I now have over 2 million dollars.

I'm just pointing out that this game should be more challenging or at least more time consuming to get up to that amount of money.

The other portion of the game I don't enjoy is you constantly have to keep fast-forwarding (don't have to but normal speed is super slow if you don't). Perhaps if the game values and progress worked at a different speed you wouldn't need to fast-forward so much.

In due time this game will get better and I can't wait to see the finish product. I'll still play regardless to dominate my competition as the most successful company in the game. I still recommend this game regardless of what I wrote, especially at the price it is at because there is a lot of features in this game, currently. I'll update my review when improvements to the game occur.

15809006.review:
[table][tr][th][h1][b]FR[/b][/h1][/th][th][h1][u]Interrogations croisées[/u] : [/h1][/th][th]-v. 0[/th][/tr][/table][i]_ _ _ entre [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/239820/]Game Dev Tycoon[/url], [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/341000/]Mad Games Tycoon[/url] & [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/362620/]Software Inc.[/url][/i]
[h1]Le genre de la Gestion est né avant-hier...[/h1]
[h1]...ça devait être un lundi, pas de chance.[/h1]
Je suis sincèrement perplexe sur le genre depuis quelques temps.
—— Avant de poursuivre, je dois dire que Software Inc. n'est pas le plus marrant et n'est pas non plus le plus complet, c'est néanmoins celui-là qui, des trois, remporte ma préférence. 
[quote][h1]Le cas Software Inc.[/h1] Early Access de contenu et de diversification.

Son apparence est stylisée (un peu) et votre bâtiment est contextualisé sur une carte (saisons, intempéries). Comme Prison Arch., c'est vous qui posez les murs de vos locaux. Vous pouvez vous agrandir, fusionner des espaces, etc. A l'intérieur, vous n'avez rien à zoner, il faut placer les meubles. La météo peut impacter vos machines, etc. La gestion de votre activité est unifiée. 

Embauchez des profils mais avec la nécessité d'avoir des personnalités compatibles. Répartissez les en équipes ad-hoc : un nouveau projet ? C'est l'équipe lambda qui s'en charge, on a besoin de liquidités rapides ? On prend un contract en parallèle et on détache 2 membres de l'équipe Lambda dans la nouvelle équipe pi qui se focalisera uniquement sur lui. Vos employés doivent manger, excréter, avoir chaud, être dans un cadre propre, confortable et fonctionnel. 

Les machines peuvent tomber en panne et ont besoin d'un technicien IT. Un tech. de surface nettoye, un concierge se charge de la clim. etc. Si votre bureau est constitué de 4 murs et d'une table, l'employé râle, le moral chute et la productivité aussi. On y remédie avec des plantes, des machines à expresso,etc. Software Inc. offre la possibilité très séduisante de gérer des étages, c'est au point mais aucun impératif ne le justifie. 

Enfin, vous concevez des jeux/OS/moteur/logiciel design Audio ou video. Si vous faite un jeu, vous aurez besoin de choisir le logiciel vidéo et l'audio en plus du moteur, la qualité du logiciel et son état technique affectent alors le jeu créé. Mais le titre ne propose aucun genre/sous genre, ni de recherche (déverrouillage dans le temps). Il est le plus maigre en contenu mais c'est aussi lui qui a le plus fort potentiel. [/quote]

[h1]Le problème[/h1]
Ces 3 titres, on jurerait qu'ils proviennent du même cahier des charges. Grossièrement, on peut même dire qu'ils partagent les mêmes faiblesses et les mêmes règles.
Je brosse le podium : Mad G. T. s'illustre par sa variété
G. Dev. T. s'illustre par sa concision et sa place de nouvel arrivant
Softw. Inc. s'illustre lui par son style et son approche plus large (Logiciel, pas uniquement des jeux/moteurs/plateformes).

Ce qui ne me va pas ? C'est simple, ils sont incomplets, en retard et dérivent de standards anormalement bas. Tantôt l'on voit de la 2D qui rappelle les pires moments du Clipart, tantôt un gameplay aussi figé et peu dynamique les pages web de la fin des années 90. Un défaut court  même, sur les 3 titres, le sentiment que chaque Asset (objet, agent) a nécessite 10 jours de brainstorming,  3 semaines en processing via une ferme de rendu et encore 2 mois d'équilibrage. Dans les faits, il faut dessiner un meuble en 2D ou en 3D et placer des chiffres derrière. Enfin, décliner ce pattern suffisamment de fois pour atteindre la variété du monde réel.

Aucun des jeux ne proposent un modèle économique poussé ou une approche vraiment créative d'un produit. 
« Alors le jeu que je veux faire,  euuh... je voudrais qu'il soit cool ! Ouai style horreur ! Après, ben, j'sais pas, en 3D pcq c'est cool aussi. Et finalement, mettons le curseur plus à droite pour de l'action dans mon jeu d'horreur et je m'en fiche du scénario. Trop bon lol, j'ai un développeur dont la jauge de connaissance en 3D est pleine, ça va aller plus vite  YOLO ! » 

[h1]Ce qui existe déjà[/h1]
Mais dans quel monde cela peut-il suffire ? 
Vous savez ce qu'ont en commun : Simcity, RollerCoaster, Industry Giant, Pizza Connection, ... Ils sont tous construit autour de 2 principes simples : satisfaire une demande, se maintenir en équilibre en le faisant... de la gestion donc. Vous savez quel est leur autre point commun ? Ils viennent tous de loin dans le passé du jeu. On ne peut pas créer un titre en ignorant tout ce qui a été fait auparavant et en reprenant tout à 0 (sauf quand on a du génie). Le trio semble nous crier « Peu importe ce qui précédé, la flem de m'y intéresser, allons-y à l'aveuglette, je vais tout réinventer, on verra bien sur le moment ! » 
Quel manque d'humilité et quel manque de respect envers le joueur. C'est une méthode de travail inquiétante, qui va à l'encontre du principe capital de la transmission du savoir « Je me sert de qui existe soit pour faire mieux, soit pour traiter autrement les problèmes que l'on y trouve ». C'est cela, qui permet à un genre d'évoluer, de passer de Wolfenstein 3D à Bioshock Infinite. Avec chaque itération, cela se raffine, s'améliore. Si chaque humain sur Terre s'attelait à recréer ses outils et ses idées, nous en serions toujours à l'âge pierre. 

[h1]Les remèdes avancés[/h1]
A ce stade, je me demande ce que nous avons bien pu faire pour mériter une punition aussi sévère que ce trio. Malheureusement, le constat s'aggrave lorsque l'on s'aperçoit que de nombreux phénomènes récents n'ont pas été modélisés. Il y a les plus subtils : la guerre des prix des revendeurs de clés, qui se positionnent comme un intermédiaire entre la distrib. numérique et le dév. Les bundles et périodes de promo débridées. La guerre entre 2 franchises, le marketing mondialisé aspirant 80% d'un budget. Un jeu devenant si populaire que tout le studio met la création en pause pour gérer la communauté et proposer du contenu, la transformation progressive des Alpha/Beta en démo et opération de com. Les outils de développement intégrés qui vont au delà d'un simple moteur de jeux. Twitch et le streaming et il en reste...
[h1]Les remèdes basiques[/h1]
On pourrait comprendre que cela soit trop lourd/complexe à modéliser/implémenter. 
Mais il reste 3 camions de points plus simples : DLC/Extensions/Stand-alone (pas juste des "suites"). Le financement participatif et ses plateformes. Le titre qui s'oriente sur la compétition et l'e-sport. Définition d'une politique sur le modding. Les circuits conférences indépendantes et les collaborations. Le merchandising. Les micro-transaction/cash-shop. La gestion de succursale/sous-traitance/rachat. Les portages, les rééditions HD, le free2play, le phénomène des Early Access, les Youtubers. (rappelons que dans GDT, le piratage était un Easter Egg)

Par contre, vous avez le bonheur de gérer les WC et leur saturation... C'est comme si SimCity offrait un bâtiment « banque du sperme » et qu'en cas de pénurie, les services municipaux cessaient de fonctionner. On croit rêver.

Si les mécanismes naturels de la concurrence étaient fonctionnels, ce sont des titres qui auraient été ignorés. Soyez prudent développeurs, le délai avant d'être rattrapé par les normes de 2015 se réduit. C'est ce que Software Inc. commence à faire...

15775714.review:
A very good game in the same vein of Mad Games Tycoon.  It's not yet at MGT's level, but it's definitely got the potential to catch up and surpass it.  There are still some bugs/improvements needed, but it's already incredible.  I can't wait to see what the finished product is like.  

Pros:
Managing teams is just complex enough to be fun without being overwhelming.
Being able to grow the building size, rather than moving as in other games allows for more "organic" growth of the business, you can look back and kind of trace your steps, which is pretty neat.
Managing the hours the staff and cleaning crews work is pretty fun, making sure no time is wasted.

Cons:
- At times employees get stuck, and it can be hard to locate them.
- Employees can at times have too much difficulty finding restrooms (and other things effecting happiness.)  I found my buildings requiring far more restrooms than would make sense in the real world.
- The room building leaves something to be desired, new rooms have to be made outside the existing walls, or must be made all the way across a room (rather than making a room from a square quarter of an existing room, you have to make a wall from the north wall all the way to the south wall, instead of north wall to middle of the west wall)  
- Not yet much customization with office items, I suspect that is coming though, this is being written just 9 days after the EA release.

Despite the cons, I promise you, this is an amazing game already.  If you're a fan of business sims, definitely pick it up!

15775145.review:
For those who want to skip the review I'll just give the conclusion Below:
This game is good, but those who want a "Software development tycoon" game, look elsewhere.
--------------------

Ok this is a very weird review for me to make because I don't think this game is bad. In fact I think this game is quite good for the right audiance.

In fact part of me likes the game and its charm. Yet I always feel that games need negative reviews in order to give people a more balanced idea of what it is being offered here.

Basically the best way I could describe the game is: What if you could build a software development factory using automotons that were fueled by coffee? and that has its appeal, it is up to you to make the best possible layout to give you the best possible results in *beep* Insert product #246 here *beep* and building your entire floorplan to make sure that your robots bump into other robots less often.

Now because your workers are robots of course your products are also made robotically. *Beep* Making Videogame #34, inserting GUI, Inserting 3d models... *Beep* basically all software is made out of lego blocks so to speak you just attach different features onto a product and the game tells you how good it "potentially" is and even how "innovative" it is (because robot). You then craft the product by working on it until it is of sufficient quality. They will even hammer it out on a keyboard as if they really were robots (and I am not convinced they arn't)

THIS is what I think the game excels at. If this makes you want to get the game do so now!

But in terms of being a software tycoon it will not satisfy. The products feel like they don't even exist within the game universe and the game has an odd way of spoonfeeding you information that you should infer yourself (How innovative a product is) as well as not telling you upfront what information you would want to know (Who is buying your product). Thus after spending a long time on what might me your magnus opus your overall attitude towards it will probably be "Ok, I guess it was made".

As well because the people are all robots and software is made of legos the whole "I am doing something creative and intellectual" aspect is kind of lost. When a game is just a list of features with "stats" on how "good" and "Innovative" it makes it, it stops feeling like a game.

Don't get the game for the wrong reasons, I hope this helped you get a bit more of an educated idea.

15761460.review:
Excellent and enjoyable game. Takes inspiration from games like the Sims and Game Dev Tycoon, but is a different game than either of those separately. Whereas Game Dev Tycoon is very limiting in what you can customize and do to expand your workspaces and capabilities, Software Inc. provides a ton of flexibility. You can build your own offices, provide additional facilities for employees in terms of food, coffee, and bathrooms. Also, you can create different teams and multiple teams of the same skillsets in order to tackle multiple project simultaneously. Managing all of these teams later in the game can prove to be welcome challenge as you assign different stages of software development to different specialized teams. 

Also, don't let the fact that this game is early access disuade you from checking it out, there are a ton of features already included in this game and it is overall very solid in terms of stability. There are bugs, but there are less than I would have expected from a one man crew putting out a game like this into early access.

15755269.review:
So I am pretty sure this is my first review ever, that's how good this game is.

Usually I am a fairly passive gamer when it comes to being involved in a community. Don't talk much on forums, don't review and I have never really tried to actively provide input and suggestions to the developers when it comes to early access games. This game changed all of that for me.

First thought on your mind is most likely; "But it is another Early Access game and too many past ones have burned to the ground". You're right, by this point so many people have been ripped off over silly development stalls and a lack of promised content. You have a right to be and if that is a position that you can't be budged from read my review and just wait, keep an eye on the game's development, watch videos, and ask players the questions you want to know about it. The developer, username: Coredumping on steam, is extremely active and responsive on the forum which is where I will start my review I suppose.

I haven't ultimately owned the game long but in about two and a half weeks (maybe less) I have put in over 50 hours XD this game is so addicting. With that said I have already talked with the developer on the forums on multiple occasions addressing bugs I had stumbled into and some small imediate suggestions I had. All of these conversations were wonderful, I felt "heard" (would it be feeling read in text forums? o.O) and I also felt like he seriously cared about what I had to say. He is very open with his project, almost all his current goals and development directions are listed on trello (https://trello.com/b/9I286Mhu/software-inc). This kind of transparency is nice as a player and supporter of his game and another reason for you to support it if this game interests you enough.

Now the game.
Like I said earlier this game is addicting or as my friend said, "This game is f*cking coke!" Be warned though, there is definitely a learning curve to running a successful long term game. I personally like this as it makes the game more rewarding to play but others may not. There is also a decent amount of content for early development, especially compared to other early access games. I would suggest watching a video for most the basic mechanics and game options but I will give you a rough overview. You get a personal character who starts a business. Hire employees, manage their salaries, educated them, and try to make the best selling software. You get to completely build and customize your Office (obviously within the limits of how he codes the construction mechanics). The building mechanics are a bit clunky and can be a trouble at times but there is a way to work around most of it's limitations with some experience at it. I am sure he will improve it as time goes but one thing for example is a second story (no matter how wide the dimensions of it's lower floor) can only have enough "structural support" to hang over one square messurement. Progress in the game feels pretty nice so far. One "day" is a month on the game calender and he has already stated he will have a time bar option to make one "day" be a week on the game calender with four weeks to a month. The game starts in 1980 unless you choose otherwise and as years pass new software and tools become available. Characters and Softwares have various details, traits and skills (characters only). The game is a bit limited on a variety of furniture/tools but stuff like that should be towards the end of alpha developement. I personally have also not come across any game-breaking bugs.

Modding: I am personally not a modder but this game as inspired me to learn a tiny bit to make some mods for this game when it drops. Right now modding is very limited to changing the values of certain mechanics and adding new companies, senarios and software. The future of modding for his game seems very appealing, he plans to have modding accessible in-game and very user-friendly. This is a huge plus in my mind as a supporter of the game because it shows that the developer understands that not only is the content he adds important but player driven content is also extremely important and he has a plan for that already.

If this review has interested you in the game even the slightest more I highly recommend watching a few videos and asking some questions on the forum. For 12 dollars this game is already very impressive and shows massive potential for a final product. Or just wait and watch it :) if I am not mistaken the game will be 12 dollars on release as well.

15739001.review:
所謂「ソフトウェア会社をつくろう！」
OSや各種ソフトウェア、アンチウイルスソフトにゲームまで
ソフトウェアを作成してお金を稼ごうぜ、的な
そんなソフトウェア会社運営ゲーム。

オリジナルブランドとしてソフトを作成するだけでなく
他社の仕事の手伝い的なものを請け負って
それを完遂させることでも報酬が貰える。
一から全てを作成するオリジナル物だと当然作業難易度が高く
付随させる機能によってはその難易度も更に跳ね上がるので
お金の無い序盤は他社からの仕事でちまちま資金稼ぎとなる。
雇う人間も選べるし、スキルアップもさせられるので
開発力を高めていきながら、より大きな案件をこなせるようになっていくところを楽しむゲームだと思う。

年代が進むと、使用するパソコンも変化するし
ソフトを製作する際に選択出来る機能も増えていく。
初期設定通りに始めると、開始は1980年からなのだが
描画は2Dしか選択肢がなく、サウンドもスピーカーのみ。
これが2000年くらいになると、64bitが選べたり
サウンドもスピーカー⇒8bit⇒HDと選択肢が増えていく。
描画にも3Dが追加され、社員のスキルでも3Dが伸ばせる様になる。

運営ゲームとしては、やれそうな事は大体やれる程度に
選択肢が存在するので、それなりにやり甲斐はあるだろう。

そこまで細部まで表現している訳でも無く
選択肢もそこまで多岐にわたる訳でもないので
お手軽なソフトウェア会社運営ゲームと言っていいと思うが
そうは言ってもスマゲー辺りとは比較出来ない程作業量はあるので
シミュゲーとしてもやり甲斐は十分あると思う。
業界の事なんて分からなくても、割と直感で分かる程度には集約されているので、普段パソゲーをやっている諸氏ならプレイに支障はないだろう。

英語が分からないと、どうすべきか悩む部分は多いと思う。
私自身英語はさっぱりなので、翻訳サイト片手にプレイしているし
ゲームの細かい所はサッパリわからないまま
なんとなくでもそれなりにプレイ出来ているので
そこまで身構えなくても大丈夫だと思う。

シミュレーション好きの諸氏に是非プレイして欲しい。

You take the roll of a Leader/Founder of a software company, hence the name. Furthermore, this is quite similar to Game Dev Tycoon, but it another way it isn't. This isn't a game for any little kid. You can't just turn it on and play it. It's very tactical indeed, without planning each release precisely, your company will most likely go bankrupt. The graphics are great, the consept is inspiring and the overall gameplay is great.

Best part of the game?

Build your own office and add a bunch of furniture inside! Hell yeah!

15673574.review:
Super interesting game, still in development and it needs a lot of work, but the developer has a very good sense of design and the mechanics are already very deep. Game has huge potential already, and the dev is extremely responsive to bug-reports and feature suggestions.

You can: 
- Take software contracts for quick cash but with steep penalties for failure.
- Run your business into the ground and lose the game.
- Take out loans to stay afloat.
- Start your own software projects, choose from a number of different types (games, game engines, OS, tools, anti-virus, etc), choose the OS(s) to build it for, choose the tools you use to make it.
- Release your product in an unfinished, broken state, but hype it to hell and make a bunch of money anyways.
- Market your software to increase awareness and marketshare
- Interview employees at a cost, choose one with the skills you need and a personality that plays
well with your other employees.
- Educate your employees on the various skills (there are a ton) and make them better.
- Negotiate wages and lowball your best employees, it's so realistic!
- Make it Open Source if you hate money (or want to handicap your competitors)
- Make it In-House to keep it all to yourself
- Build an office and keep it clean and working. Make sure it's quiet, clean and comfortable to keep coders happy.
- Buy servers to run your network based programs, and keep your Source Control repos on to keep your projects safe.
- Trade in the stock market
- Curse when your employees call in sick on the last day before the work is due.
- Choose your distribution channel, or start your own if you've got the infrastructure. Charge money for mods and start a firestorm. (not really, that's crazy)
- Tons more

There are a couple negatives atm, like blah graphics and animations, a couple bugs and weird behaviors, not very many options for purchasing furniture or decoration right now, and game pace that's just slightly out of whack. But the dev is hard at work and is constantly listening to the player-base on things that need to change or improve, and I really expect that most of these issues will be resolved before long. Definitely worth a try, I do this all day at work and still want to play this game when I'm home, for some reason.

15664747.review:
Im Folgenden werde ich das Spiel "Software Inc." bewerten.

HINTERGRUND

Du startest ein kleines Entwicklerstudio mit einem kleinen Budget. Während du versuchst mit diversen Softwareentwicklungen Geld in die Kassen zu spülen (hört sich leichter an als es ist) baust du dein Studio aus. Nahc dem ersten - mehr oder weniger - großen Erfolg, bist du bereit erste Angestellte einzustellen, um dich an größeren Projekten zu versuchen. Im Laufe der Zeit wächst dein Unternehmen und deine Dienstleistungen gewinnen an Komplexität.


GRAFIK

Die Grafik ist Alpha. Ganz klar. Jedoch lässt sich der spätere Grafikstil schon erahnen, welcher in meinen Augen sehr gut zum Spiel selbst passt. Dies heist jedoch nicht, das es im Moment grottig aussieht. Es ist eben nur kein Augenschmaus.


Sound

Es gibt (noch) keinen. Lediglich wenige Hintergrundgeräusche.


GUI

Gewöhnungsbedürftig. Das Spiel ist sehr komplex, was dazu führt, dass es viele unterschiedliche Knöpfe gibt, was schnell den Überblick verlieren lässt, wenn man neu ist.


Gameplay

Gut. Wenn man sich ein wenig eingespielt hat und weiß worauf es ankommt steht  eurem Entwicklerstudio nichts mehr im Wege.


KAUFEN ODER NICHT KAUFEN?

Software Inc. ist ein Spiel mit viel Potential, was aber jetzt durchaus gut spielbar ist, da fast nur kosmetische Implementierungen fehlen. Aber vorsicht es ist ein Alpha-Titel, also noch unfertig.
Für den Preis lohnt es sich auf jeden Fall.

15661636.review:
I really like this game. I'm glad I bought it.
I will probably play this for years.

The graphics are basic, but the style is quite aesthetically pleasing.
The game is a Business Sim, but its multifaceted and I'm not bored at all.
The UI is very well done, intuitive, and best of all.. it works.

Software is complicated, and this game demonstrates a working knowledge of development processes.
If you work in software development, or are an enthusiast, you will recognize the skills and terms immediately.
It just feels so genuine and not detached from reality, despite being a game. 

The atmosphere, style and substance of this product is significant.
I should also mention: ITS FUN. 

10/10 - Would restore my faith in Early Access again.

Qualifiers: 
- I have only played this game for a day and I'm writing this review in Early Access. 
- This is a positive review very early in Early Access. 
- I couldnt wait any longer to write the review.
- I am a customer.
- I am very pleased with my purchase. (nice price too btw)

15645494.review:
I love the Idea of this Game so far, It's like the off-spring of Game Dev Tycoon and Sims that was mentored a little by Prison Architect. Growing up to be such an addictive game, but it still has some learning to do before it can be well-known and loved. It offers some quite different gameplay from GDT, Sims, and Prison Architect, allowing you to take the seat of a founder of a software company similar to Microsoft, Sony, and other companies out there. You are able to build a company from a simple plot of land to a Major Gaming industry giant or a popular company known for making a Anti-virus programs, Game engines, and even Art software similar to Gimp. The choice is up to you what your company is known for, how your base of operations is built (and colored), and how to manage your employees through their needs and wants. Though this Game may be young and needs time to be develop, still it seems impressive for what it offers so far. There are some tiny bugs wondering around the game, they are barely noticeable. 

I have posted a video on Youtube that gives you an view of the game (listed below) and I plan on making a Let's play series on it. (*Warning*: I may be Loud and Unprofessional when talking, but will not say any Bad words or mean things)
https://youtu.be/xeU1PUNVRpI 

Also I recommend playing the Demo (shown in video) as well if you want to experience some of the gameplay yourself, but there will some bugs that may occur during it.

15638750.review:
If you take "Game Dev Tycoon", pump it full of steroids, and add little bit of "The Sims", you'll come up with "Software Inc.".  In addition to creating software, games, engines, and taking contracts, you'll be able to create a character, hire employees, customize your teams, see to your employees' needs, build the office building from the ground up, buy/sell stocks, manage an insurance account, and more.  It all can be a bit overwhelming at first, but it's totally worth checking out if you enjoyed playing the aforementioned game-maker simulator.  It has a few bugs, but nothing that will ruin the experience.

15638425.review:
[h1]Baue dein eigenes Software Unternehmen auf[/h1]

Dieses Review wurde mit einem Presse-Key erstellt

In Software Inc. baut man seine eigene Software Entwicklungs Firma auf, man kann alles entwickeln, von der eigenen GameEngine, über Spiele und Antiviren-Programme, bis hin zum eigenen Betriebssystem.
Am Anfang baut man sich ein kleines Häuschen in dem man noch allein ein paar Programmier-Aufträge erledigt, bis man sich genug Geld verdient hat, um ein ganzes Entwicklerstudio mit Angstellten zu besetzen und irgendwann eigene Spiele und Programme zu entwerfen, welche je nach Popularität und Umfang, mehr oder weniger Lukrativ sind.

Man fängt wahlweise zwischen 1980 und 2010 an, 1980 ist nur ein alter PC und ein schwacher Server verfügbar, außerdem kann man nur textbasierte Spiele entwickeln, nach und nach werden aber immer mehr Sachen frei geschaltet, wie z.B. ab Jahr 2020 ein Holo-PC...

Das Spiel findet am Anfang hauptsächlich im Erdgeschoss statt, jedoch kann man auch noch im Keller und bis in den 10. Stock über dem Erdgeschoss bauen. Das Areal ist mit 73.984 Quadraten extrem groß, womit man einiges anfangen kann.

[h1]Pro[/h1]
+ Schöne Grafik
+ Viele Baumöglichkeiten
+ Einige verschiedene Optionen, Geld zu verdienen
+ Detailierte Informationen zu allem und jedem
+ Mods sind geplant
+ Mit der Zeit gibt es neue Sachen zu entdecken
+ Verschiedene Teams
+ Sehr großes Areal das bebaut werden kann
+ 12 Etagen

[h1]Neutral[/h1]
Englische Sprache (Übersetzungen der Community sind inzwischen verfügbar)

[h1]Kontra[/h1]
- Bisher keine Musik (was aber auch sein gutes haben kann)

[h1]Fazit:[/h1]
Es ist ein innovatives Game, das sehr viel Spaß macht und zum Ausprobieren anregt, da eigentlich nichts unmöglich ist.
Klare Kaufempfehlung, vorallem da der Preis später auch noch steigen wird, während die Entwicklung voran schreitet.
